Biography: Philip lists his Father, who "died at Chapultepec" fighting in the Mexican-American War, as one of the ancestors who have born the name "Backhouse" with honor (682).

SourceTextTitle: "My Grandmother Millard and General Bedford Forrest and the Battle of Harrykin Creek"
Biography: Philip lists his Uncle, who ran unsuccessfully "for Governor of Tennessee" on what was obviously a pro-slavery platform, as one of the ancestors who has born the name "Backhouse" with honor (682).

SourceTextTitle: "My Grandmother Millard and General Bedford Forrest and the Battle of Harrykin Creek"
Biography: Granny Millard's dead husband owned a "supply house" in Memphis (688). One of his customers was Nathan Bedford Forrest, who (although the story never mentions it) was a well-known Memphis planter and slave-dealer at that time. He and Forrest "sometimes" sat together on the front porch and "sometimes" ate together too (688).

SourceTextTitle: "My Grandmother Millard and General Bedford Forrest and the Battle of Harrykin Creek"
Biography: "General Smith" is the commander of the Union forces that Philip attacks. Bayard's narrative never gives him a first name. There were two Union Generals named Smith who fought Confederate Nathan Bedford Forrest in Mississippi at various times after the fall of Vicksburg. General William Sooy Smith was defeated by Forrest on February 22, 1864, in the Battle of Okolona. However, most scholars assume the General Smith in Faulkner's story is Andrew Jackson Smith, who fought Forrest at the Battle of Tupelo in July, 1864. Faulkner had a particular reason to know this Smith: also in 1864 he was in command of the soldiers who burned both Oxford (the original of Jefferson) and Ripley, where among the houses they destroyed was the home of Colonel William Falkner, the author's great-grandfather.

SourceTextTitle: "My Grandmother Millard and General Bedford Forrest and the Battle of Harrykin Creek"
Biography: This icon represents the group of men "in gray" on horseback whom Philip leads (689). When Bayard sees them in the yard at Sartoris, he says there are "at least fifty of them" (689).

SourceTextTitle: "My Grandmother Millard and General Bedford Forrest and the Battle of Harrykin Creek"
Biography: This icon represents the five Confederate cavalrymen who accompany General Forrest on his visit at the Sartoris plantation. Bayard says they are "all officers," adding that "I never saw this much braid before" (691). Granny refers to them as "gentlemen," and the story confirms that when it describes how carefully they avoid "trombling even one flower bed" on the plantation lawn (691).

SourceTextTitle: "My Grandmother Millard and General Bedford Forrest and the Battle of Harrykin Creek"
Biography: This icon represents the "two soldiers in one of General Forrest's forage wagons" who bring Lucius back to Sartoris (690). As foragers, these men were charged with finding food for the troops in the surrounding countryside - a common practice in the Confederate Army during the Civil War.

SourceTextTitle: "My Grandmother Millard and General Bedford Forrest and the Battle of Harrykin Creek"
Biography: The "provost" who arrests Philip for disobeying orders (692). In the Confederate armies, provosts were charged with maintaining discipline - like military police in the modern U.S. armed forces. (The second time the story refers to him, "Provost" is capitalized, 694.)

SourceTextTitle: "My Grandmother Millard and General Bedford Forrest and the Battle of Harrykin Creek"
Biography: Forrest tells Granny that he has placed Philip "in close arrest, with a guard with a bayonet" (694) - this is that guard.

SourceTextTitle: "My Grandmother Millard and General Bedford Forrest and the Battle of Harrykin Creek"
Biography: A General in the Confederate Army. Although in the story Forrest says General Johnston is "at Jackson" in Mississippi, at the time of the battle of Harrykin Creek - April 1862 - he was actually fighting in Virginia. (He was put in charge of Confederate forces in the western theater of the war, which included Mississippi, at the end of 1862.)
OtherTexts: "Retreat", Absalom, Absalom!, Flags in the Dust, Requiem for a Nun, The Reivers , The Unvanquished

SourceTextTitle: "My Grandmother Millard and General Bedford Forrest and the Battle of Harrykin Creek"
Biography: The "chaplain" who marries Philip and Melisandre is an officer serving in Forrest's troop (699).

SourceTextTitle: "My Grandmother Millard and General Bedford Forrest and the Battle of Harrykin Creek"
Biography: Four officers - "in their gray and braid and sabres" - accompany Philip and the chaplain to the wedding at Sartoris (699). This group might include some of the five officers who came to Sartoris earlier with Forrest, but that is not directly said or suggested in the text.

The only child of Wesley Pritchel, Ellie is a "dim-witted spinster of almost forty" (113) when she marries Joel Flint. After their marriage, she farms and raises chickens in a small house built on the Pritchel farm for approximately two years until she is murdered by her husband.

"Indians had owned it" (90) - this refers specifically to Houston's land, but historically the Chickasaw Indians occupied most of the land in what became northern Mississippi (including the area in which Faulkner locates Yoknapatawpha). Under the Presidency of Andrew Jackson they were "removed" beyond the Mississippi RIver, and most of the tribe was gone from Mississippi by the mid-1830s.

These "people" are obliquely evoked when the narrator says that the "mounds of rotting sawdust" marking the sites of the sawmills that once turned all the trees around Frenchman's Bend into lumber are the "monuments of a people's heedless greed" (190).
This unnamed deputy accompanies the sheriff to investigate the initial call from Joel Flint about his wife's death. He may or may not be the same as one of the named deputies in the story.

Gavin Stevens is one of Faulkner's favorite characters. A Harvard graduate, he chooses to stay close to home, serving as the County Attorney for Yoknapatawpha in several of Faulkner's texts. In this story, as in the other stories in Knight's Gambit, he acts as both amateur detective and crusader, helping the sheriff solve the mysteries of Ellie Flint's death and Joel Flint's identity. As he tells the sheriff, he's "interested in justice and human beings" (115).
OtherTexts: "A Name for the City", "By the People", "Go Down, Moses", "Hair", "Hand Upon the Waters", "Knight's Gambit", "Monk", "Smoke", "The Tall Men", "Tomorrow", Go Down, Moses, Intruder in the Dust, Light in August, Requiem for a Nun, The Hamlet, The Mansion
social_status: has influential social contacts (family, business, political)

Biography: Charles Mallison, Jr., is his birth name, Charles Mallison is the name at the top of all the chapters he narrates in The Town, but readers of the Yoknapatawpha fictions probably know him best by his nickname - Chick - which is what his uncle Gavin and V.K. Ratliff, the novel's other two narrators, generally call him. He is the youngest member of one of the oldest and most prominent Jefferson families. Although he was not born when the events of the narrative begin, Charles narrates 10 of the novel's 24 chapters, including the first and the last. He says he has learned about events before his birth from his cousin Gowan. He is recruited by Gavin and Ratliff as their messenger and assistant in keeping a wary eye on the Snopeses, particularly Flem. The professed focus of The Town is on the progress of the Snopes family in Jefferson, but it is also is about Chick's growth from childhood (when he cannot understand most of what the other two narrators tell him about Eula Snopes, or her lover, or her husband) through adolescence (when he can experience firsthand the desire that Eula inspires in all the men who see her) to a maturity that enables him to understand her tragedy and the larger social forces at work in the story. As a narrator, Charles is clear and astute with a wry style of reporting on the characters and events.
OtherTexts: "A Name for the City", "An Error in Chemistry", "By the People", "Knight's Gambit", "Monk", "Tomorrow", Intruder in the Dust, The Mansion

Biography: Concerning "Cousin Gowan," Charles Mallison says, "his grandfather was Grandfather's brother . . . he just called all of us except Grandfather 'cousin' and all of us except Grandfather called him 'cousin'" (3). He returns to Jefferson to live with the Mallisons while his parents are abroad, and while living there becomes part of Gavin Stevens and V.K. Ratliff's unofficial campaign against Snopesism. Later he is the reliable source for much of what Charles himself narrates about the early years of that campaign, since Charles, as he says in the novel's first words, "wasn't born yet" (3). To build his strength before "going out for the football team," he works one summer in the power plant, where he comes into direct contact with one of Flem's schemes (17). Although Gavin's narrative is pervasively mediated by Charles' voice, Gavin's own perspective can be identified as that of a youth becoming an adolescent, and curious about the ways adults behave.

Gavin Stevens is one of the three major narrators of The Town - and, given the amount of time the other two narrators spend describing his behavior and opinions, probably its central character. He is the son of Judge Lemuel Stevens, twin brother of Margaret Mallison, and uncle of Chick Mallison. He is Yoknapatawpha's most educated inhabitant, with degrees from Harvard, Heidelberg and the University of Mississippi. He serves Yoknapatawpha officially as, in turn, the City and the County Attorney, but is even more diligent in his attempts to save both Jefferson at large and the two women in Flem Snopes' life from the modern malaise he associates with the Snopes family. He is an idealistic, obsessively talkative, and optimistic man, often given to considering complexities, especially his own; he is smitten by Eula Snopes and later, in a different way, by her daughter Linda, and is troubled by his desires for them: "contriving by clumsy and timorous artifice the accidental encounters in which he still would not and never quite touch, really want to touch, too terrified in fact to touch; but only to breathe the same air, be laved by the same circumambiance which laved the mistress's moving limbs" (219). His opposition to the Snopeses and to Manfred de Spain is absolute, but rarely effectual. One of Faulkner's favorite characters, he appears in 16 Yoknapatawpha fictions, often in a major role.
OtherTexts: "A Name for the City", "An Error in Chemistry", "By the People", "Go Down, Moses", "Hair", "Hand Upon the Waters", "Knight's Gambit", "Monk", "Smoke", "The Tall Men", "Tomorrow", Go Down, Moses, Intruder in the Dust, Light in August, Requiem for a Nun, The Mansion

Biography: Judge Lemuel Stevens is the patriarch of the family that includes his son, Gavin Stevens; daughter, Maggie; her husband, Charlie Mallison; and their son, Chick. "Grandfather" is the patriarch in the Stevens household until his death "in the last year of the war" (119) - i.e. World War I, so 1918. When Gavin sues Manfred de Spain to disrupt Manfred's affair with Eula Snopes, Judge Stevens says to his son, "'So you dont want him not to be mayor . . . Then what is it you do want? for him not to be alive? Is that it?'" (104).
OtherTexts: "An Error in Chemistry", "Knight's Gambit", "Tomorrow", Intruder in the Dust, The Mansion, The Reivers

Biography: Gowan Stevens' father works for the State Department. When he is assigned to "China or India or some far place" (3), he sends his son to Jefferson to stay with his Stevens cousins.
Gowan Stevens' mother accompanies her husband for the duration of his State Department assignment to "some far place," which explains why her son Gowan came to Jefferson (3).

Twin sister of Gavin Stevens and mother of Chick Mallison, Maggie is married to Charley Mallison. Lively, articulate, and energetic in her several roles as wife, mother, and twin sister, she is also intelligent and humorous and at base a kind person, as we see when young Linda Snopes comes to her home for Sunday dinner. As a prominent member of Jefferson society, she willingly aids her brother in his determination to have Eula Snopes accepted by the ladies of the town. She also has a clear vision of her fellow Jeffersonians. About Eula, for example, Maggie says, "The ladies of Jefferson dont care what she does. What they will never forgive is the way she looks. No: the way the Jefferson gentlemen look at her" (50). In response, Charley says, "Speak for your brother . . . I never looked at her in her life," and Maggie retorts, "Then so much the worse for me . . . with a mole for a husband. No: moles have warm blood; a Mammoth Cave fish" (50).
OtherTexts: "Knight's Gambit", "Tomorrow", Intruder in the Dust, Requiem for a Nun, The Mansion

Biography: Charles Mallison, Sr., sometimes called "Charley" in the novel, is husband to Margaret Mallison, brother-in-law of Gavin Stevens, and father of Chick Mallison. A conventional businessman of his time and place, he owns a livery stable and is initially opposed to and resentful of those who purchase automobiles. A well-read and clever man, he enjoys lively exchanges with his wife, and he often teases his brother-in-law about Gavin's infatuation with Eula Snopes. His role in the life and education of his son is secondary to "Uncle Gavin"'s.
OtherTexts: "An Error in Chemistry", "By the People", "Knight's Gambit", Intruder in the Dust, The Mansion

SpecificJob: Restaurant Owner, Power Plant Superintendent, Banker
Biography: Nominally the central character of The Town, and of the larger Snopes Trilogy, Flem Snopes is the son of Abner Snopes, the husband of Eula Varner Snopes, the putative father of Linda Snopes, and the anxious focus of Gavin Stevens and V.K. Ratliff, two of the novel's narrators. His story can be seen as both a cautionary tale about the modernist forces that threaten the South's traditional social and moral order - this is the role in which the novel's narrators generally cast him - or as a southern variant of the American dream of rising from poverty to wealth and status - this is the way Gavin depicts him in Chapter 17. Like Thomas Sutpen, the protagonist of Absalom, Absalom!, Flem's life begins at the bottom, as the poor white son of a shiftless tenant farmer. In The Town he arrives in Jefferson as the new partner in a disreputable side-street restaurant who lives with his family in a tent; by the end he is the new president of the Sartoris bank and moving into the De Spain family mansion. His success is grounded in a combination of intelligence, determination, secrecy, and a willingness to employ nepotism, thievery, and unscrupulous financial influence. His relationship with Eula's lover, Manfred de Spain, called "amicable cuckoldry" by Stevens and Ratliff, is a form of extortion or blackmail on the part of Flem. He is first described as "a squat uncommunicative man with a neat minute bow tie and opaque eyes and a sudden little hooked nose like the beak of a small hawk" (4). His behavior intrigues, puzzles, and angers the novel's narrators, who even argue among themselves about his true motivations. Money, his means if not always his goal, figures prominently in his sequence of ventures. He is apparently prepared to use his daughter, Linda, as well as his wife to achieve his ambition. In her last conversation with Stevens, Eula explains Flem's behavior and concludes: "You've got to be careful or you'll have to pity him. You'll have to" (347).
OtherTexts: "Barn Burning", "By the People", "Centaur in Brass", "Lizards in Jamshyd’s Courtyard", "Spotted Horses", As I Lay Dying, Flags in the Dust, The Hamlet, The Mansion, The Reivers

Biography: Daughter of Will Varner, the richest man in Frenchman's Bend, Eula is married to Flem Snopes after she becomes pregnant by another man. She arrives in Jefferson with her illegitimate child in a wagon pulled by mules and driven by Flem's ambition. Her sexual power has a mythic status; Charles Mallison describes Eula's effect on men: "There was just too much of what she was for any just one human female package to contain and hold: too much of white, too much of female, too much of maybe just glory . . . so that at first sight of her you felt a kind of shock of gratitude just for being alive and being male at the same instant with her in space and time, and then in the next second and forever after a kind of despair because you knew that there never would be enough of any one male to match and hold and deserve her" (6). Maggie Mallison expresses the female point of view concerning Eula: "The ladies of Jefferson dont care what she does. What they will never forgive is the way she looks. No: the way the Jefferson gentlemen look at her" (50). With an impotent husband, she turns to the town's most eligible bachelor, Manfred de Spain, with whom she has an affair that lasts almost two decades; even in this transgressive role, however, she can be seen as a victim, since her husband exploits the affair to further his own career. Eula's later concerns center on her daughter's happiness: she becomes Gavin's ally in attempting to separate Linda from Flem, and even exacts a promise from Gavin (to whom she once offered herself) that he will marry Linda. Eula's fate is a tragic one, although her final sacrifice serves to free Linda. It also allows Flem - in one last, ironic exploitation of her - to erect a monument to her as "A virtuous Wife" and "a Crown to her Husband" (372).
OtherTexts: "Centaur in Brass", "Spotted Horses", Flags in the Dust, The Hamlet, The Mansion

Biography: Linda is the natural daughter of Eula Varner Snopes and a Frenchman's Bend suitor named McCarron. Although Linda lacks her mother's voluptuous appeal, she is very attractive to men in her own right, as the reactions from Chick, Gavin, and Matt Levitt all demonstrate. She seems like contested territory on a number of fronts; various people attempt to direct her education, inheritance, and marital status throughout the novel. While Eula exacts a promise from Gavin that he will marry her daughter, Linda herself is reluctant to accept his conditional offer of matrimony. At the end of the novel, her mother's suicide releases Linda from her Jefferson ties, and with her 'father's' permission and Gavin's assistance, she leaves Jefferson for Greenwich Village, which Gavin calls "a place with a few unimportant boundaries but no limitations where young people of any age go to seek dreams" (367). Her future in New York and beyond plays out as one of the central narratives in The Mansion, the final volume in the Snopes trilogy.
OtherTexts: "Centaur in Brass", "Spotted Horses", Flags in the Dust, The Hamlet, The Mansion

Biography: "Ratliff sat there with his bland brown smoothly-shaven face, and his neat tieless blue shirt and his shrewd intelligent eyes" (7). V.K. Ratliff, a sewing machine salesman and traveler covering four counties (and also one of Faulkner's favorite characters), is a bachelor, intelligent, observant, and highly articulate in his regional vernacular. One of the three main narrators of The Town, certainly the most succinct, knowledgeable, and humorous of them, Ratliff helps the others keep track of the Snopeses' behavior in Jefferson, particularly that of Flem Snopes. He eventually discerns the pattern in Flem's treatment of his kinsmen and the rest of Jefferson, but Gavin does not "get it," and Ratliff expresses his frustration in one of Faulkner's rare brief chapters: "Because he missed it. He missed it completely" (160; reiterated 186). Eula Snopes acknowledges having private conversations with Ratliff, in one of which he reveals to her his personal secret: that V.K. stands for Vladimir Kyrilytch, a family name passed down through the generations since the American Revolution (337-39).
OtherTexts: "A Bear Hunt", "By the People", "Centaur in Brass", "Lizards in Jamshyd’s Courtyard", "Spotted Horses", As I Lay Dying, Flags in the Dust, The Hamlet, The Mansion

Biography: As Mink is being driven to jail, they pass the Whiteleaf store. When the men who had been "squatting and spitting on the gallery stand suddenly up," the deputy sheriff remarks that "There are folks here too that act willing to believe their name is Houston for maybe ten or fifteen minutes anyway" (283).

This icon represents the group whom Lump Snopes refers to as "a few of the boys" (258). They don't appear directly in the narrative, but Lump tells Mink his plan to take these young white men one night to the home of the Negro who found Mink's shotgun, and terrify him "with a couple of trace chains or maybe a little fire under his feet" in order to force him to admit, falsely, that he stole the gun (258).
One of the deputies who help the Sheriff capture Mink is named Jim. He drives the surrey in which they carry the prisoner back to Jefferson.
One of the deputies who help the Sheriff capture Mink is named George. He objects to the Sheriff's decision to take Mink to jail by a back route.

CharacterName: Unnamed Descendants of the Frenchman's Slaves
Biography: The descendants of the slaves who once worked on the Old Frenchman's plantation are identified as "saxophone players in Harlem" (375). With this reference the narrative looks ahead both to the Great Migration in which thousands of southern blacks moved to northern cities (which was just beginning at the time the novel takes place) and to the Jazz Age of the 1920s.
Sort Name: Unnamed Descendants of the Frenchman's Slaves
CharacterKey: Unnamed Descendants of the Frenchman's Slaves

FirstAppearence: Railroad Station where Man is Shot
Biography: The crowd at the "bleak" railroad station where Labove sees a white man shoot a black man "scatters" as the shooting occurs, then forms a "crowd" around the Negro so dense that Labove has to "use his football tactics" to move through it; some of them also "overpower and disarm" the white man (138).

Part-owner of the backstreet restaurant Flem Snopes co-owns when he first comes to Jefferson, Grover Winbush eventually becomes the night watchman in Jefferson. His other nighttime activity is revealed when the Atelier Monty is raided. (In The Hamlet, as Ratliff's partner, he is named Aaron Rideout.)

Home: Old Man Snopes' House outside Town
Biography: Ab Snopes, Flem's father in a number of Yoknapatawpha fictions, is an elusive figure in The Town. In Chapter 1 Charles reports him as having been hanged during the Civil War as a horse thief - right before Ratliff tells Gavin Stevens that "about ten years ago Flem and an old man who seemed to be his father appeared suddenly from nowhere one day and rented a little farm from Mr Will Varner" (5). (Ab may appear again in Chapter 8, as the irascible old man who lived just outside of Jefferson with a watermelon patch that he fiercely guarded: some folks say he "Mr Flem's father" but others identify him as "just his uncle" (136). However, we have decided to identify this angry old man as a brother of Ab.)
OtherTexts: "Barn Burning", "My Grandmother Millard and General Bedford Forrest and the Battle of Harrykin Creek", "The Unvanquished", "Vendee", The Hamlet, The Mansion, The Unvanquished

Biography: The first "Colonel Sartoris" to be mentioned in this novel is John, a leading figure in Yoknapatawpha County, and one of the major figures in the Yoknapatawpha fictions (5) - although with one exception (148) everywhere else in the novel "Colonel Sartoris" refers to John's son, Bayard II on the larger Sartoris family tree - though in the novel the name Bayard refers exclusively to Bayard III. (It's not clear why Faulkner creates this potential source of confusion.) In any case, the next time John Sartoris is mentioned, he appears at "old Colonel Sartoris, the real colonel" (43), and for the sake of clarity that - Old Colonel Sartoris - is the name we give him here. Colonel Sartoris in this novel provides the occasion for the original connection between the Sartoris and Snopes families: according to this account, Flem's father Ab Snopes served "in Colonel Sartoris's cavalry command in 1864" (5). Decades later, after the Old Colonel's son founded the Sartoris bank, he hired a Snopes - Byron - as a sentimental tribute of sorts to his father and the other "heroes of our gallant lost irrevocable unreconstructible debacle" (44).
OtherTexts: "Ambuscade", "Barn Burning", "My Grandmother Millard and General Bedford Forrest and the Battle of Harrykin Creek", "Raid", "Retreat", "Shall Not Perish", "Skirmish at Sartoris", "The Unvanquished", "There Was a Queen", "Vendee", Absalom, Absalom!, Flags in the Dust, Go Down, Moses, Light in August, Requiem for a Nun, The Hamlet, The Mansion, The Reivers , The Sound and the Fury, The Unvanquished

Biography: Father of Eula Varner Snopes, but never really present as a character, Will Varner is nonetheless a major figure in the background of The Town. "Mr Will Varner . . . just about owned the whole settlement and district called Frenchman's Bend about twenty miles from Jefferson" (5). He lets his son Jody rent "a farm so poor and small and already wornout that only the most trifling farmer would undertake it" (5) to Ab Snopes - without realizing that he is also mortgaging a part of his life to Ab's son Flem. Irascible and impatient, Will was quick to marry off Eula to Flem when she became pregnant by another man; he himself has had three Negro mistresses with whom he has had a number of illegitimate children. Although he rarely appears directly in this novel, he plays an important role in several of its financial crises, especially when Manfred De Spain leaves Jefferson and Flem becomes president of the bank.
OtherTexts: "By the People", "Fool About a Horse", "Lizards in Jamshyd’s Courtyard", "Shingles for the Lord", "Spotted Horses", "The Hound", "Tomorrow", As I Lay Dying, Flags in the Dust, Intruder in the Dust, Light in August, The Hamlet, The Mansion

Biography: Jody Varner, the son of Will Varner, manages many of his father's businesses in Frenchman's Bend.
OtherTexts: "Fool About a Horse", "Spotted Horses", As I Lay Dying, Light in August, The Hamlet, The Mansion

Biography: Linda's biological father was a stranger to Yoknapatawpha named McCarron; he became Eula's first lover after he fought off the "five Frenchman's Bend boys" who ambushed them (105) - an event described at more length in The Hamlet. In The Town Gavin describes him to Eula as "that other one, that first one - your child's father" and speculates that this man must have been "the only other one" - besides De Spain - she's ever had sex with (100). (In the earlier Hamlet his first name is given as "Hoake"; in the later The Mansion, it's "Hoke" again.)
Chapter One calls the Confederate soldier who wounds Ab Snopes a "picket" (5); in Chapter Two, he is identified as a Confederate "provost-marshal" (43).

When Ab Snopes moves to Frenchman's Bend, "another Snopes" appears "from somewhere to take over the rented farm" (6). Most of the Snopeses start out as tenant farmers, but there's no indication that this particular "Snopes" is one of the male Snopeses to whom the narrative gives a first name, though that is possible.

This "Texas feller," Flem's partner in the sale of the wild spotted ponies (35), is not named in The Town , but he is identified as "Buck" or "Buck Hipps" elsewhere. Unlike Flem, he has scruples about how far he's willing to go to separate the poor whites of Frenchman's Bend from their hard-earned money.
Ratliff recalls that he and Henry Armstid were tricked into buying the Old Frenchman Place by Flem Snopes, who convinced them that Civil War treasure was buried there.
OtherTexts: "Lizards in Jamshyd’s Courtyard", "Shingles for the Lord", "Spotted Horses", As I Lay Dying, Light in August, The Hamlet, The Mansion

Biography: Eck Snopes, the father of Wallstreet Panic and Admiral Dewey Snopes, is described first as "another Snopes accreted in from Frenchman's Bend into the vacuum behind the first one" (9). But to Gavin, he seems too generous and good-hearted to be a member of the Snopes family. Gavin says that Eck is "indubitably and indefensibily not a Snopes," arguing that Eck's mother "had, must have, as the old bucolic poet said, cast a leglin girth herself before she married whatever Snopes was Eck's titular father" (33) - which is Gavin's way of saying he believes Eck is illegitimate, not biologically a Snopes. After breaking his neck saving the life of a Negro mill hand, Eck "was a threat to his whole family's long tradition of slow and invincible rapacity because of that same incredible and innocent assumption that all people practise courage and honesty for the simple reason that if they didn't everybody would be frightened and confused" (34). He loses his job in Flem's cafe when he naively but honestly announces that the hamburgers he cooks "aint [made from] no beef" (34). "All the boys in town" appreciate his willingness to share his "raw peanuts" with them (116). He dies searching for a missing boy when he holds a lantern flame over one of the oil company's open storage tanks.

Previously a saw mill engineer, Harker is now the engineer in the Jefferson power plant. He enjoys making sarcastic remarks about the principal actors in the maneuverings around the embezzled brass fittings: Tom Tom Bird, Tomey's Turl Beauchamp, and Flem Snopes. For example, Harker says, "'If Turl ever is unlucky enough to get married he would still have to climb in his own back window or he wouldn't even know what he come after" (24). He does, however, actively intervene when he helps the two black firemen recognize their real antagonist.

Joe Buffaloe is the "city electrician" who maintains the town's generators and dynamos and transformers (12). He is also a "genius," who "in 1904 . . . drove out of his backyard into the street in the first automobile we had ever seen, made by hand completely" (12).
OtherTexts: Requiem for a Nun, The Mansion, The Reivers

Biography: Manfred de Spain appears in the novel as "mayor of the town," "president of one of its two banks and a warden of the Episcopal church" (282) - but especially as Eula Varner Snopes' lover for 16 years, which for very different reasons puts him at odds with the puritanical part of the town's population, with Eula's husband Flem (who nonetheless tacitly blackmails De Spain into helping him up the ladder of success), and with Gavin Stevens, the chivalrous champion of Eula's honor. The De Spain family is among the most prominent in Jefferson; Manfred's father was a Confederate officer (the real "Major de Spain") and, for two days, a Governor of Mississippi (10). "De Spain himself was a West Pointer who had gone to Cuba as a second lieutenant with troops and came home with a wound - a long scar running from his hair through his left ear and down his jaw" (11). When he is elected mayor by the votes of the younger generation, "it was a landslide because more than just he had won, been elected. The new age had entered Jefferson"; Manfred's sporty and noisy EMF Roadster, one of the first cars in Jefferson, symbolizes his role as the "champion, the Godfrey de Bouillon, the Tancred, the Jefferson Richard Lion-heart of the twentieth century" (13). A lifelong bachelor, he leaves town after Eula commits suicide in 1927.
OtherTexts: "A Bear Hunt", "Shall Not Perish", "The Bear", "The Old People", The Mansion, The Reivers

Biography: This is the father of Mayor Manfred de Spain; he was "a real major of Confederate cavalry" (10) and an early investor in the bank of Jefferson.
OtherTexts: "Barn Burning", "Delta Autumn", "Lion", "The Old People", "Wash", Absalom, Absalom!, Go Down, Moses, Intruder in the Dust, The Hamlet, The Mansion, The Reivers , The Town

Biography: He is the Jefferson mayor who precedes Manfred de Spain in the office: "the mayor with a long patriarchal white beard, who probably seemed to young people like Cousin Gowan older than God Himself, until he might actually have been the first man" (11).

The "old fat wife" of Mayor Adams and mother of Theron Adams (11). To the younger people in Jefferson, she and her aged husband are disparagingly called Adam and "Miss Eve Adam" - a "fat old Eve" too old to tempt or be tempted (11).
The youngest son of Mayor Adams and Eve Adams, Theron declines to accept Manfred de Spain's challenge to fight him.

This man works for the Sartoris family and drives a horse-drawn carriage rather than a car. He is holding the reins when Mr. Buffaloe drives his homemade automobile "into the square at the moment when Colonel Sartoris the banker's surrey and blooded matched team were crossing it on the way home" (12). (He is probably Simon Strother, but this novel doesn't give any details about him so that identification is too speculative; on the other hand, when this same event is described in The Mansion, the unnamed Negro coachman is described with details that make it clear that Faulkner is thinking of Simon.)

For a long time prior to 1904, at least according to Charles' narrative, "the young people" of Jefferson accepted the rule of their elders, but De Spain's candidacy for mayor "was the opportunity which that whole contemporary generation of young people had been waiting for, not just in Jefferson but everywhere," to change the status quo (12). As voters, this younger generation gives De Spain a landslide victory: "they had displaced the old dug-in aldermen and themselves rode into office as the city fathers on Manfred de Spain's coat-tails" (14).
A major figure in other Faulkner fictions, especially Go Down, Moses, Ike McCaslin in this novel is the owner of the Jefferson hardware store and a member of a prominent Yoknapatawpha family.
OtherTexts: "A Bear Hunt", "Delta Autumn", "Fool About a Horse", "Lion", "Race at Morning", "The Old People", Go Down, Moses, Intruder in the Dust, The Hamlet, The Mansion, The Reivers

Biography: This all-purpose butler performs general duties in for Manfred de Spain's house, and lives in Manfred's "late father's big wooden house" (14).
This cook lives and works in Manfred de Spain's "late father's big wooden house" (14).

Thirty years old, confident, and amorous, Tomey's Turl puts his life at risk by pursuing Tom Tom Bird's young wife. (In Go Down, Moses "Tomey's Turl" is the name of the enslaved, illegitimate and incestuously conceived character from whom all the black Beauchamps descend; he was born in 1833, whereas the Tomey's Turl in The Town must have been born after 1880. The relationship between these two characters with the same name is never explained.)

Tom Tom Bird is "a big bull of a man weighing two hundred pounds and sixty years old but looking about forty and married about two years ago to his fourth wife: a young woman whom he kept with the strict jealous seclusion of a Turk in a cabin about two miles down the railroad track from the plant" (16). For twenty years he has worked at the power plant in Jefferson as the day fireman - that is, the kind of fireman who shovels coal to keep the plant's fire going.

Tom Tom is married to his fourth wife, who is "new" and "young" and willing to entertain Tomey's Turl while her husband is at work in the power plant (22). After Tom Tom ends the affair, she joins the rivals in hiding the stolen brass.
A group of "archaeologists from the State University" dig up Native American relics from Pritchel's clay pit until he runs them off with a shotgun (119).

Bryan Ewell is a deputy sheriff whom the sheriff orders to guard Wesley Pritchel's house after Pritchel has locked himself in his room (122). (Bryan may be related to Walter Ewell, who appears in six other fictions, but there is no mention of any relationship.)

The two men "in spectacles" who audit the accounts of the Jefferson power plant are presumably employed by the state, or perhaps by the company that bonds local officials (22). According to Mr. Harker, "They went over the books and poked around ever where, counting ever thing in sight and writing it down" (22).
The city clerk collects a check for $218.52 from Flem Snopes for the missing brass.

He is the Jefferson marshal and father of Buck Connors II. (His name is spelled "Conner" in "Centaur in Brass" and Light in August, and he is probably also the "Buck" who appears in Flags in the Dust.)
OtherTexts: "Centaur in Brass", Flags in the Dust, Light in August

Biography: Tom Tom Bird's "substitute, who fires the boilers on Sunday" (26), also fills in for him when Tom Tom keeps lookout at home.

Otis is "nephew or cousin or something" of the Harker who is the engineer at the town's power plant. Although he has "inherited the saw mill" that the older Harker originally ran, Otis fills in at the power plant "whenever Mr. Harker wanted a night off" (26). By the end of the novel he has become Jefferson's "night marshal"; Gavin Stevens calls him one of Yoknapatawpha's "minor clowns" (334).
This is the "somebody at the City Hall" who is informed about the missing brass fixtures at the power plant and calls in "the auditors" to investigate the matter (31).

The woman who gave birth to Eck is unnamed. When he introduces her into the story, Gavin Stevens asserts that she "must have, as the old bucolic poet said, cast a leglin girth herself before she married whatever Snopes was Eck's titular father" (33) - by which he is saying that Eck 'must' be illegitimate. The only basis for this, however, is Eck's honesty and decency combined with Gavin's own antipathy to all things Snopes: he and Ratliff see Eck as too good a human being to be genetically a Snopes.

Neither of Eck's parents appear directly in The Town, but two of the novel's narrators - Ratliff and Gavin - do discuss his parentage. Based on their contempt for 'Snopeses,' they both feel strongly that since Eck is so good a person, genetically he is "not a Snopes" (32). Thus they invent this "titular father" for him: the imaginary man with whom Eck's mother had an affair (33).
Ontological Status: Created by a Character in Text

Biography: This man, whom Gavin Stevens calls "one of the larger ones and of course the more imbecilic," joins Eck in attempting to set "a tremendous cypress log . . . onto the saw-carriage" (33). When the man slips and falls, Eck saves his life by holding up his own end of the log "until it occurred to someone" to get the Negro out from under it (33).

In this novel Eck's wife is the mother of Wallstreet Panic and Admiral Dewey Snopes. When Eck dies, she receives a thousand dollars and invests the money in Wall's grocery store. (On the other hand, in the earlier novel The Hamlet, Eck marries a second wife after his first one dies, and Wallstreet and Ad have different mothers.)

Wall Snopes (originally Wallstreet Panic) is a determined and ambitious son of his honest father, Eck: "Every morning Wall would get up before schooltime, as the days got shorter he would get up in the dark, to build a fire in the iron stove and sweep out the store and as soon as he got back after school in the afternoon he would be the delivery boy too, using a wheel barrow" (135). He believes in the value of an education, entering kindergarten as a pre-adolescent and making rapid progress through the grades. He proposes marriage to the schoolteacher who gave him his first formal education, then marries the girl she picks out for him instead. As an adult, the young man "who was never a Snopes, never in this world a Snopes" (152) becomes an honest and successful owner of a prosperous grocery business, bringing modern retail and wholesale methods to Yoknapatawpha. Throughout his rise he refuses to take any help from his relative, Flem Snopes.
This entry represents the "half a dozen strangers not even kin to Snopeses by marriage" who are eating in the restaurant when Eck asks about what is really in the hamburgers he's cooking (34).

Mrs. Littlejohn owns a boarding house in Frenchman's Bend. Ratliff tells the story of her "coming onto the back gallery with an arm full of washing in one hand and the washboard in another" after the auction of the spotted horses and finding a horse on her porch: "she split the washboard down the center of its face and throwed the two pieces at it without even changing hands" (36). (This story is told at more length in the earlier story "Spotted Horses" and the first novel in the Snopes trilogy, The Hamlet.)
OtherTexts: "Lizards in Jamshyd’s Courtyard", "Spotted Horses", Flags in the Dust, The Hamlet

Biography: This "strange Negro youth" (129) is sitting in the driver's seat of Wesley Pritchel's truck as the disguised Joel Flint prepares to sell the property and leave. "Strange" in this context almost certainly means 'not from Yoknapatawpa.' The youth has presumably been hired by Flint to drive the truck.
Cal Bookright is the father of Zack Houston's wife; at first, he opposed his daughter's marriage to Houston. (In the other texts where he appears, his name is spelled "Bookwright.")

A secret fraternal order originating in medieval ritual, the Masons advocate charity and obedience. Eck was an active member among the Frenchman's Bend Masons, and Will Varner encouraged the Masons in Jefferson to find an appropriate job for Eck after his neck was broken. When Eck dies, they bury him, displaying their ritual "aprons" and "signs" at his funeral (117).

According to Joel Flint, impersonating Wesley Pritchel, the old man had "four children," all of whom have died (130); Joel is just mean enough to include the one he killed, Ellie, in this count. As Ellie Flint (nee Pritchel) she has her own entry in the database.
Though the narrator is unnamed in this story, he is apparently Charles "Chick" Mallison, Jr., so the dead father he briefly mentions (132) would be Charles Mallison, Sr.
OtherTexts: Intruder in the Dust, The Mansion, The Town

Biography: Gavin Stevens describes him: "I.O., the blacksmith-cum-schoolmaster-cum-bigamist, or -times bigamist, multiplied by bigamy - a thin undersized voluble weasel-faced man talking constantly in a steady stream of worn saws and proverbs usually having no connection with one another nor application to anything else, who even with the hammer would not have weighed as much as the anvil he abrogated and dispossessed" (37). He is the father of Montgomery Ward by his first wife and Vardaman, Bilbo, and Clarence by his second wife. His last appearance in Jefferson features his encounter with Miz Mannie Hait and Flem Snopes over some mules. (Readers of The Mansion, the Snopes novel that followed The Town, learn that "I.O." probably stands for "Initials Only.")
OtherTexts: "Mule in the Yard", "Spotted Horses", Flags in the Dust, Sanctuary, The Hamlet, The Mansion, The Sound and the Fury

Biography: Trumbull is the blacksmith in Frenchman's Bend, "man and boy for fifty years" until Flem tries to install two of his cousins, I.O. and Eck, in his place (38). When they prove their incompetence, Trumbull is restored to the position.

Zack Houston is the husband and widower of Letty Bookright. A proud, prosperous, and hot-tempered farmer, he lost his wife when his prized stallion killed her. Houston himself was killed by Mink Snopes. (In The Hamlet his first name is Jack.)
OtherTexts: "The Hound", As I Lay Dying, The Hamlet, The Mansion

Biography: I.O. Snopes' second wife, who "wasn't a big girl neither - Miz Vernon Tull's sister's niece by marriage she was" (39), is the mother of Clarence, Vardaman, and Bilbo. In her character as "Clarence Snopes' maw" - as Ratliff refers to her (384) - she summons the men at Varner's store to rescue her son from "Them Indians!" - as she refers to Byron's children (388); Ratliff credits her "mother love and mother instinct" for knowing that her son's life was in danger (388).
Sort Name: Snopes, Second Wife of I.O. Snopes

Biography: This woman is the mother of Montgomery Ward Snopes. She appears suddenly in Frenchman's Bend after I.O. has married his second wife and fathered three children with her. She becomes the proprietor of the Snopes Hotel in Jefferson, which caters to a lower-class, usually country-bred, clientele. (In Flags in the Dust, however, the Snopes who takes over the hotel is Clarence's mother - which according to The Town would be I.O.'s second wife.)
Sort Name: Snopes, First Wife of I.O. Snopes

Biography: Bilbo is the son of I.O. Snopes and his second wife and the twin to Vardaman Snopes. The man after whom he is named, Theodore G. Bilbo, was a well-known white supremacist in Mississippi.

Vardaman is the son of I.O. Snopes and his second wife and twin brother to Bilbo Snopes. He is named for James K. Vardaman, a well-known white supremacist who served as both a Governor of Mississippi and a United States Senator.

"A Bear Hunt" opens with this unnamed narrator, whose role is essentially to frame the first-person vernacular tale told by Ratliff that will be begin on the fourth page of the text. He provides some necessary background information about the story's characters and settings, including Ratliff and Lucius Provine, and the Indian mound and settlement. Although he tells us very little about himself, except to identify his family as "literate, town-bred people" (65), he appears to be an adult resident of Jefferson who, when he was fifteen, actually met some of the Chickasaws and spent a night on the Indian mound with another boy. Though unidentified in the magazine and Collected Stories versions of the story, in Faulkner’s revision of the story in Big Woods, the narrator identifies himself as General Compson's grandson, suggesting that he is Quentin Compson, whom Faulkner also uses as a first-person narrator in several other short stories in addition to his major appearances in The Sound and the Fury and Absalom, Absalom!.

Ratliff is a traveling sewing machine salesman who tells the story of Luke Provine's bout with hiccups and his own part in helping 'cure' them. A garrulous man of the people, Ratliff speaks in a folksy vernacular that stylistically sets him apart from the story's more formal frame narrator. He himself becomes a butt of the joke he tries to play on Provine when, unbeknownst to him, Ash appropriates his scheme for his own purposes - an ironic outcome that Ratliff accepts with good humor. Ratliff is a frequent character and narrator in Faulkner’s fiction, playing a major role in the Snopes trilogy: The Hamlet, The Town and The Mansion. In the first published version of the story in The Saturday Evening Post, he was identified as V. K. Suratt; for the revised versions of the story in Collected Stories and later in Big Woods, following his practice in later works in which this character occurs, Faulkner changed his name to Ratliff.
OtherTexts: "By the People", "Centaur in Brass", "Lizards in Jamshyd’s Courtyard", "Spotted Horses", As I Lay Dying, Flags in the Dust, The Hamlet, The Mansion, The Town

Biography: Major de Spain is a wealthy landowner in Jefferson and the owner of a fishing and hunting camp near the Tallahatchie River in northern Yoknapatawpha County. Perhaps because he owns the camp, or perhaps because of his higher class status, De Spain is considered the leader of the group who gather for roughly two weeks in the fall of each year to hunt bear, deer, and other game. Like several other characters in this story, "Major de Spain" appears in a number of Faulkner novels and short stories, as a name for two different characters, a father and a son. From the date of the events in "A Bear Hunt," this De Spain must be the son, Manfred de Spain - who inherited the title of "Major" from his father, who in fact served in the Civil War with that rank. But Manfred is usually depicted as a bachelor (though he is given a son in "Shall Not Perish"), and this story's first narrator notes that he has a wife and married daughters. The narrative itself reveals him to be impatient and domineering, which is certainly characteristic of Manfred elsewhere. (In Faulkner's revised version of the story in Big Woods, this character is explicitly identified as the son of "old Major de Spain.")
OtherTexts: "Shall Not Perish", "The Bear", "The Old People", The Mansion, The Reivers , The Town

Biography: In his accounting for Ratliff's presence at the hunting camp, the story's frame narrator mentions a "Mrs. de Spain," wife of the man who owns the camp (63). She does not appear in the story, and all the narrator says about her is that "doubtless [she] already owned" a sewing machine, unless she gave it to one of her daughters (63).

Major de Spain has several married daughters who, the unnamed narrator speculates, might have been given a sewing machine by Mrs. de Spain. Manfred is usually depicted as a bachelor, but a son of his is mentioned in "Shall Not Perish." (This De Spain, Manfred, is usually depicted as a bachelor, but a son of his is mentioned in "Shall Not Perish.")

A major character in the story, the man whom the frame narrator calls "Lucius" and Ratliff calls "Luke" Provine is a hanger-on at the hunting camp who is suffering from a persistent case of hiccups and who becomes the butt of a practical joke when he goes to a nearby Indian mound to seek a cure for it. A "tall, apparently strong and healthy man . . . who makes no effort whatever to support his wife and three children" (64), he is described by the narrator at the beginning of the story as forty and almost toothless, as well as violent, shiftless and boozy. Twenty years earlier he was notorious in the region as the leader of a "gang" of delinquents; one of the gang's actions in that past gives rise to the story's main events. (In almost every respect this character seems identical with the character of Lucius Hogganbeck, who appears in 3 other texts - and in Faulkner’s revision of "A Bear Hunt" story for Big Woods, he renamed the character "Lucius Hogganbeck.")
OtherTexts: The Mansion, The Reivers , The Town

Biography: Lucius Provine's wife who, the story says, receives no financial support from her husband. The narrator implies she is the principal breadwinner in the family, with money she "earned by sewing and such" (64).
The children of Luke Provine. The story makes only one direct reference to them, saying their father "makes no effort whatever to support his wife and three children" (64).

The dead brother of Luke Provine. According to the narrator, it has been "years now" since he, Luke, and another man, Jack Bonds, "were known as the Provine gang and terrorized our quiet town after the unimaginative fashion of wild youth" (63-64).

This general group consists of the various residents of Yoknapatawpha County who appear in the story, especially those encountered by Ratliff in his travels as a sewing machine salesman; specifically mentioned are "farmers' wives" at bazaars and sewing bees and "men and women at all-day singings at country churches" (63). This group also includes the few unnamed people referred to in the story who are not included in some other group.

This group represents unnamed people who live in town rather than out in the county. At one point the narrator characterizes them generationally: "younger citizens of the town" who know Luke Provine only as a healthy, shiftless man who “makes no effort whatsoever to support his wife and three children,” and "older men who remember the Butch . . . Provine of twenty years ago," when he still possessed a "driving, inarticulate zest for breathing which has long since burned out of him" (64).

This group of "ladies," most of whom are likely residents of Jefferson, are described by the narrator as "scurrying and screaming" when the Provine gang, some twenty years earlier, would occasionally "terrorize" them by galloping horses in their midst as they were going to or from church on Sunday mornings (64).

The narrator of "A Bear Hunt" identifies a group of men who, "since the last year years, cannot find work" (64). The chronological reference probably points to the Great Depression of the 1930s, an era defined by mass unemployment and what the story calls "men among us now whose families are in want" (64). Also according to the narrator, in an apparent contradiction to the rest of the passage, "these [men] all attain and hold to a "certain respectability" as salesmen of "minor articles like soap and men’s toilet accessories and kitchen objects," which they carry around town in black sample cases (64). (At first the narrator is surprised to see Lucius Provine with such a case, but within a week it is "discovered that it contained whisky in pint bottles," 64.)

These town officers appear to be law enforcement officials who, less than a week after Luke Provine appears in town carrying a black sample case, discover that what he is selling is bootleg whisky, a serious crime in Yoknapatawpha, which like the rest of Mississippi prohibited the sale of alcohol - not only during, but also before and after Prohibition. (Mississippi did not legalize liquor until the 1960s.) The story suggests they arrest Provine for his crime, but allow Major de Spain to "extricate" him from the charge (64).

Clarence is the son of I.O. Snopes and his second wife and brother to Vardaman and Bilbo Snopes. According to Ratliff, he is "a big hulking man now eighteen or nineteen, who was all a gray color" (386). He is "the only Snopes or resident of Frenchman's Bend or Yoknapatawpha County either for that matter" to welcome Byron Snopes' wild children - who in turn try to burn him at the stake (387).
OtherTexts: "By the People", Flags in the Dust, Sanctuary, The Mansion

Biography: The son of I.O. Snopes and his first wife, Montgomery Ward is extremely dishonest and selfish. When the U.S. enters World War I, he dodges the impending draft by joining Gavin Stevens for service with the Y.M.C.A. in France, where he "looks around" at the opportunities offered by the war (111). Eventually he sets up a brothel in Paris. Returning to Jefferson after the war, he dresses like a French bohemian - wearing "a black suit and a black overcoat without any sleeves and a black thing on his head kind of drooping over one side like an empty cow's bladder made out of black velvet" (127) - and carrying "a passel of French postcards" (171). The "bladder" is a beret, and the postcards are pornographic. In what he calls his "Atelier Monty," he poses as a photographer while actually showing his French pornography at night to a large clientele of men from Yoknapatawpha and beyond (172). He is eventually exposed, although his cousin Flem and the town's officials conspire to preserve Jefferson's reputation by having him convicted of running a bootlegging operation rather than a peep show.
OtherTexts: Flags in the Dust, The Hamlet, The Mansion

Biography: Not named in The Town, he is the father of Byron and Virgil Snopes and schoolmaster in Frenchman's Bend. (He is identified as Wesley Snopes in The Mansion.) He also has a presence in the religious life of the community. Although he is as unqualified to preach as he is to teach, he is a revival preacher "whose stage and scene were the scattered country churches and creeks and horse-ponds where during the hot summer Sundays revival services and baptisings took place: himself (he had a good baritone voice and probably the last working pitch pipe in north Mississippi) setting the tune and lining out the words, until one day a posse of enraged fathers caught him and a fourteen-year-old girl in an empty cotton house and tarred and feathered him out of the country" (43).

Byron Societies were originally literary groups that met to read and discuss the works of George Gordon, Lord Byron. By the time of this novel, the Jefferson version of the Byron Society was essentially a social club for aristocratic and middle class women. Like the Cotillion Club, membership in the Society confers social prestige. Of the Bryon Club, Maggie Mallison says, "it had been a long time now since anybody listened to anybody read anything because they played bridge now but at least she said that when it met with Miss Jenny Du Pre they had toddies or juleps instead of just coffee or coca colas" (325).

The all-male transient residents of the Snopes Hotel are described by Gavin as "itinerant cattle drovers and horse- and mule-traders" who are in Jefferson on business and "juries and important witnesses" who stay there "during court term" (41). According to Gavin, these patrons are "incarcerated, boarded and fed" (41).

Admiral Dewey Snopes is the younger son of Eck Snopes and the brother of Wallstreet Panic Snopes. He begins kindergarten at the age of six with his nine years' older brother as a classmate and assists Wall in his commercial endeavors. (Admiral George Dewey, after whom this Snopes is named, was one of the heroes of the Spanish-American War.)

The potential customers asking for directions to the Snopes Hotel are "country men" - men from the countryside outside Jefferson - who "were told simply to walk in that direction until they came to a woman rocking, and that was it" (42). (The woman is I.O. Snopes' wife.)

Byron is the son of "actual schoolmaster" Snopes and the brother of Virgil Snopes. Byron serves for a time as a bookkeeper in the Sartoris bank, "the low last man in that hierarchy," before absconding with as much cash as he can get his hands on (45). By the end of the novel he is somewhere in the American southwest and has fathered four wild children with a Jicarilla Apache woman. Byron sends these children by rail from El Paso to Jefferson, where they cause various threats to the community, at some cost to Byron's cousin Flem.
OtherTexts: "There Was a Queen", Flags in the Dust, The Mansion

Biography: Virgil is the son of the man identified only as "the actual Snopes schoolmaster" (42), and the brother of Byron Snopes.
These men - all "enraged fathers" - tar and feather "actual schoolmaster" Snopes for taking advantage of an adolescent girl (43).

This icon represents the group that Gavin Stevens refers to, with a mix of cynicism and sentimentality, as the "heroes of our gallant lost irrevocable unreconstructible debacle" - the aging Confederate veterans who "half a century" after the end of the Civil War are revered by "all" the people of Yoknapatawpha (44). As Charles Mallison explains, the descendants of these men are often "called General or Colonel or Major because their fathers or grandfathers had been generals or colonels or majors or maybe just privates" (10). The military titles of two major characters in The Town - "Colonel" Bayard Sartoris and "Major" Manfred de Spain - are of this honorary nature, inherited from their fathers.

FirstAppearence: Cotton House Where Wesley Snopes Is Caught
Biography: This girl is discovered in an "empty cotton house" having sex with "schoolmaster" Snopes (43).

The character whom the narrators of the novel call "Colonel Sartoris" inherited his title as the son of Colonel John Sartoris. In most other Yoknapatawpha fictions he is called by his name, Bayard Sartoris, though in the next Snopes novel, The Mansion, the narrators again refer to him only as "Colonel Sartoris." In those other fictions there is no record of his being in the Civil War at all, but here Gavin Stevens calls him "our present banker-honorary colonel who had been only an uncommissioned A.D.C. on his father's staff, back in that desperate twilight of 1864-65" (43). In this novel he is defined almost entirely by his actions as the founder and first president of the Sartoris bank, which is the point where his life intersects Flem Snopes'. Faulkner provides a new detail concerning him, his bank and Byron Snopes, the Snopes who figured most prominently in Flags in the Dust (1929). It turns out that Colonel Sartoris hired Byron out of loyalty to the memory of his father's command. Sartoris was badly frightened by an automobile, which led him to try banning them in Jefferson; it seems ironic, then, that he is killed in an automobile accident. His death precipitates a series of changes in both the bank's leadership and the social structure of Jefferson.
OtherTexts: "A Rose for Emily", "Ambuscade", "My Grandmother Millard and General Bedford Forrest and the Battle of Harrykin Creek", "Raid", "Retreat", "Skirmish at Sartoris", "The Unvanquished", "There Was a Queen", "Vendee", Flags in the Dust, Go Down, Moses, Requiem for a Nun, The Hamlet, The Mansion, The Reivers , The Unvanquished

Biography: Aleck Sander, whose mother, Guster, works for the Mallisons, is Chick Mallison's contemporary and boyhood companion. His older brother is Top. Aleck Sander hunts rabbits with Chick and Chick's three white companions. (Aleck Sander is not a first and last name, but the way his given name, Alexander, is invariably spoken; the novel does not give him or his other family members a last name.)
Guster is wife to Big Top and mother to Little Top and Aleck Sander. She works for the Mallisons as a cook. She was named "Paralee" in the earlier novel Intruder in the Dust.

Melisandre Backus lives on a plantation "about six miles from town" and was a friend of Maggie Mallison's in high school and at the Jefferson seminary (52). At one time, Maggie had hoped that Gavin would marry Melisandre. (He does in the last volume of the Snopes trilogy.)

Mr. Backus is the father of Maggie Mallison's friend Melisandre: "He was a good farmer. He just spent the rest of his time sitting on the gallery in summer and in the library in winter with the bottle, reading Latin poetry" (52).
When this woman learns that Maggie Mallison has called on Eula Snopes, she condescendingly reproves Maggie.
This is the woman identified as "the second lady" who condescendingly reproves Maggie Mallison for calling on Eula Snopes (53).

As Charles Mallison notes in his narrative, "he was Guster's boy and his father was named Top too so they called him Big Top and Top Little Top" (55). Charles however always calls him "Top" in the few places where he appears. He and Gowan Stevens try to help Gavin by setting a trap for De Spain's car.
Big Top is Guster's husband and father to Aleck Sander and Little Top. Only his name appears in the narrative (55).
Buck Connors II is the son of Marshal Buck Connors and friends with Chick Mallison. Chick remembers him as one of the boys who was hunting with him along Harrykin Creek.
Ashley Holcomb is one the boys in the Harrykin Creek hunting party.

A friend of Chick Mallison, John Wesley is among the five boys who go rabbit hunting on a winter day at Harrykin Creek. In an elaborate series of dares, he trades a dollar he owes Aleck Sander for being shot in the back, although it's said that since Ab Snopes has already done this, Aleck Sander isn't getting a fair trade because "John Wesley knew what to expect" (57-58).

Lucius Hogganbeck borrowed money "to buy a Model T Ford and set up in the jitney passenger-hauling business . . . and Mr de Spain and Lucius would race each other. Lucius would charge his passengers a nickel a head to ride in the race, though Mr de Spain carried his free" (61). (In The Reivers it turns out that he is the son of Boon Hogganbeck, but there is no hint of that in this novel.)
OtherTexts: "A Bear Hunt", The Mansion, The Reivers

Biography: Roth Edmonds had employed Lucius Hogganbeck's father, Boon, and may have signed the note that enabled Lucius Hogganbeck to buy his Model T Ford. Also known as Carothers Edmonds, this man plays a major role in Go Down, Moses (1942).
OtherTexts: "A Point of Law", "Go Down, Moses", "Gold Is Not Always", "Pantaloon in Black", "Race at Morning", Go Down, Moses, Intruder in the Dust, The Reivers

Biography: Lucius Hogganbeck's father, Boon, had worked for the McCaslin, Edmonds, and De Spain families as "huntsman-doghandler-manFriday back in the time of Major de Spain's old hunting camp" (61). He is a major character in Faukner's last novel, The Reivers, and probably best known as the man who killed Old Ben in "The Bear."
OtherTexts: "Lion", "The Bear", "The Old People", Go Down, Moses, Intruder in the Dust, The Reivers

Biography: McCaslin Edmonds is the cousin of Ike McCaslin and the father of Roth, though elsewhere he is the father of Zachary (who in turn in Roth's father). He plays a much larger role in Go Down, Moses than in this novel; his family takes over Ike's property after he abdicates responsibility for it.

These men are described as Jefferson's "storekeepers and doctors and lawyers and mayors and such as that"; their "quiet and peaceful" suppers are disturbed by the sound of Manfred De Spain's car when he passes by the Mallison house (62).

Chick's father - Charles Mallison, Sr. - owns the town livery stable. He notes that because so "many of my customers use horses and mules for a living," it would be bad for his business if he owned an automobile (65).

Although his soubriquet labels Uncle Noon Gatewood according to the demeaning conventions of Jim Crow culture, he is one of the few Negro businessmen who appear in the fictions. He is the "big and yellow" owner of a "blacksmith shop on the edge of town": "he had a warped knee that just seemed to fit exactly into the break of a horse's forearm and pastern; he would pick up a horse's hind leg and set the foot inside the knee and reach out with one hand and take hold of the nearest post" (68).

Jabbo Gatewood is the son of Uncle Noon Gatewood, a blacksmith. In a sign of social change, he becomes an automobile mechanic: "Jabbo was the best mechanic in the county and although he still got drunk and into jail as much as ever, he never stayed longer than just overnight anymore because somebody with an automobile always needed him to pay his fine by morning" (71).

General Compson was a Confederate brigadier and for two days governor of Mississippi (72-73). These positions explain the only detail about him the novel provides: the many floral arrangements at his funeral. As the grandfather of Quentin Compson, he plays a crucial role in Absalom, Absalom!, and he is the character who appears most frequently in the collected Yoknapatawpha fictions.
OtherTexts: "A Justice", "Appendix: Compson", "My Grandmother Millard and General Bedford Forrest and the Battle of Harrykin Creek", "The Bear", Absalom, Absalom!, Go Down, Moses, Intruder in the Dust, Requiem for a Nun, The Reivers , The Sound and the Fury, The Unvanquished

Biography: Gavin Stevens' determination to send a corsage to Eula Varner Snopes begins what Charley Mallison calls the "Mrs Rouncewell panic" (81). Mrs. Rouncewell is Jefferson's florist: "She ran the flower shop; not . . . because she loved flowers nor even because she loved money but because she loved funerals; she had buried two husbands herself and took the second one's insurance and opened the flower shop and furnished the flowers for every funeral in Jefferson since" (73). (In three other texts the name Rouncewell is associated with a boarding house, not a flower shop, but we are presuming this character is the same "Mrs. Rouncewell" who runs the boarding house in The Mansion.)

Servant of Major de Spain who accompanies the white hunters each fall. Ratliff describes Ash as "Major's nigger, a-helping around camp" (67), but he appears to be the highest ranking of the black servants at the camp, in charge of the kitchen and controlling the "jug" of whisky (68). As a black servant, Ash is overlooked by the white men in camp - Ratliff admits at the beginning of his tale that he "never knowed who Old Man Ash was, no more than Luke did" (67) - but Faulkner's narrative reveals Ash to be observant and smart: when he overhears Ratliff's suggestion that Luke seek a cure for his hiccups from John Basket near the Indian mound, he immediately recognizes an opportunity to get revenge against this one white man. In the original Saturday Evening Post publication of the story, his character was named Old Man Bush. For both Collected Stories and Big Woods, Faulkner changed his name to Ash; in the latter volume, he is further described as son of "Ash Wylie."
OtherTexts: "The Bear", "The Old People", Go Down, Moses

FirstAppearence: First Hunting Stand in Big Woods
Biography: Ike McCaslin is a major character in several of Faulkner's fictions, especially Go Down, Moses. But in this earlier story, he is simply one of the poker-playing hunters at Major de Spain's camp who complains about how the noise from Luke’s hiccups would scare away game, saying, "Do you reckon any varmint in the world is going to walk up to a hay baler?" (69). There is no mention of the family he belongs to, but his dialect ("noways," "durn," 74) suggest he is probably lower class.
OtherTexts: "Delta Autumn", "Fool About a Horse", "Lion", "Race at Morning", "The Old People", Go Down, Moses, Intruder in the Dust, The Hamlet, The Reivers

Biography: John Basket is a Chickasaw who lives in the settlement near the Indian mound, and well-known as moonshiner who makes what Major de Spain describes as "bust-skull whiskey" (75). Basket unwittingly becomes an accomplice in Ash's practical joke against Luke Provine when Ratliff offhandedly suggests Luke visit him to get a cure for his hiccups.

One of the hunters at Major de Spain's camp, seen only in a brief scene in which he is playing poker. His only real significance in the story is to represent the annoyance the rest of the hunting party feels at Luke Provine's bout of hiccups.

This group represents the unnamed African-Americans in the story who are not included in some other group: the blacks at the picnic who were not physically abused by the Provine gang, and the people whom the narrator refers to as "Negroes among us living in economic competition" with the white society; this latter group is identified as having "our family names" - i.e. the same last names as people in the white community (66).

These black men were at a Negro church picnic some twenty years ago when they were set upon by the pistol-wielding Provine gang, then taken "one by one" and tormented and demeaned by having the celluloid shirt collars they wear burned, "leaving each victim’s neck ringed with an abrupt and faint and painless ring of carbon" (65). The ring may have been "painless," but the psychological scar it left is not - as beccomes clear when it is revealed at the very end of the story that one of men who was forced to wear it is Ash.

CharacterName: Unnamed Negro Men at Hunting Camp
Biography: An unspecified number of black men are present in the camp to cook and do other odd jobs during Major de Spain's annual hunting trip. As blacks and as servants, they tend to be ignored or not noticed by the white hunters except when they are sought for some reason, as happens when Major de Spain calls for Old Man Ash to fetch him a drink when Ash has gone to the Indian mound. One of these other black servants appears with the "demijohn and fixings" and reports that Ash has gone "up to'ds de mound" and would be back by daylight (74).
Sort Name: Unnamed Negro Men at Hunting Camp
CharacterKey: Unnamed Negro Men at Hunting Camp

Biography: The Chickasaw Indians inhabited northern Mississippi at the time the first white settlers arrived. In this story Faulkner imagines that a "remnant" of the tribe remains in Yoknapatawpha in the 1930s, living together "under Government protection" (65), but historically, the entire tribe was "removed" beyond the Mississippi River a hundred years earlier, during the presidency of Andrew Jackson. The story's "Chickasaws" do not directly appear, but they play a role in the imagination of the county's young white boys, whose ideas of "Indians" are derived from reading "dime novels": they were "a little fabulous, their swamp-hidden lives inextricable from the life of the dark mound . . . as though they had been set by the dark powers to be guardians of it" (65-66). The pivotal role they play in the story's narrative, when they threaten to torture a man they believe is a federal agent in order to protect their moonshining operations, could also be said to derive from popular stereotypes.

Friends of the unnamed narrator who associate the Indian mound with "secret and violent blood" and a "savage and sudden destruction" (65). As descendants of "literate, town-bred people," their feelings about the "profoundly and darkly enigmatic mound" stem from their romantic ideas about Indians gotten from the "secret dime novels which we passed among ourselves" (65). One of the boys joins the narrator for a night atop the mound.

One of the boys in town who, "on a dare," joins the unnamed narrator when he was fifteen to spend a night on the Indian mound (66). During and afterwards, they do not speak about their experience, apparently awed by it; the narrator says even though they were children, "yet we were descendants of people who read books and who were - or should have been - beyond superstition and impervious to mindless fear" (66).

An unspecified number of white men are present at Major de Spain’s annual hunting camp. Ratliff comments indirectly on the size of the group, saying he was not surprised that Luke Provine would be there because "this here would be the biggest present gathering of men in the county, let alone the free eating and whisky" (68). As alluded to in the title, some may be bear hunters, while others are referred to by Major de Spain as "shotgun fellows on the deer stands" (68). When not hunting, the camaraderie of camp life includes eating, drinking, and playing poker.

A "revenue agent" was an employee of the U. S. Treasury Department charged with enforcing the Volstead Act prohibiting the manufacture and sale of alcoholic beverages during the Prohibition era. Old Man Ash invents this character, telling John Basket and the other Indians (who are making moonshine) that Luke Provine was a "new revenue agent" coming to catch them making illegal whisky (78).
Ontological Status: Created by a Character in Text

Biography: The first people Ratliff encounters upon returning to Jefferson after his misadventure at the hunting camp. Two of them ask about his facial injuries - one in standard English, one in a country vernacular - and their questions provide Ratliff with a way to begin his story. They don't seem to be the "you" (67), however, to whom he "is telling" the story itself (63).

A Union general during the Civil War, William Tecumseh Sherman was notorious in southern lore and history for his 'total war'concept of destroying property in occupied Confederate territory to remove sources of food and equipment needed to sustain southern armies and to erode the morale of soldiers and civilians alike. He was perhaps most despised by many southerners, even generations after the war, for his 'march to the sea' through Georgia from Atlanta to Savannah in November-December 1864, in which his army cut a swath of destruction 50 miles wide. The unnamed frame narrator of the story refers to "the lost Civil War and Sherman’s march" as examples, like the Indian mound, of things that were "as much a part of our lives and background as the land itself" (66).
OtherTexts: "Raid", "Wash", Flags in the Dust, The Reivers , The Unvanquished

Biography: A "dead and forgotten contemporary" of Luke Provine when he was a young man. According to the narrator, it has been "years now" since Bonds, along with Luke and Luke's unnamed brother, "were known as the Provine gang and terrorized our quiet town after the unimaginative fashion of wild youth" (63-64).

CharacterName: Unnamed Husbands and Beaus of the Ladies in the Club
Biography: These "husbands and beaus" reluctantly bought at least one corsage for their Cotillion Club partners, following Gavin's example (73).
Sort Name: Unnamed Husbands and Beaus of the Ladies in the Club
CharacterKey: Unnamed Husbands and Beaus of the Ladies in the Club

Biography: This character owns the tailor shop in Jefferson, where he tailors men's clothes and rents out formal menswear, such as the tuxedos worn to the Cotillion Club ball.

Weddel is pursuing Sally Priest, a married woman, and sends her a corsage before the Cotillion ball. His first name, Grenier, comes from one of the founding Yoknapatawpha families - but the novel says nothing about a genealogical connection to that family.

Sally Priest, an abused married woman, receives a corsage from Grenier Weddel and a black eye from her husband. According to Gowan Stevens' account, "you would even have thought she was proud of it" (81); according to Ratliff's, "she was" (82). Her maiden name, "Sally Hampton" (80), suggests she is related to the Hamptons who are county sheriffs in other fictions, but if Faulkner imagined her in that relation, the text gives no hint of it. (When The Town was reprinted in 1964, the names of the two Priests were changed to "Parsons," perhaps to avoid confusion with the many members of the very different Priest family who appear in Requiem for a Nun [1962] - though Faulkner did not usually worry about creating such kinds of confusion.)

A surviving descendant of one of Jefferson's founders, Eunice Habersham drives the "home-made truck that she peddled vegetables from" for the florist (74). She delivers Manfred de Spain's "corsage" to Gavin Stevens, along with another four for Maggie. (She plays much more important roles in both Intruder in the Dust and (as Belle Worsham) in Go Down, Moses.)
OtherTexts: "Go Down, Moses", Go Down, Moses, Intruder in the Dust

Biography: The Jefferson couples who receive invitations to the Cotillion Dance represent the most socially approved people in town. Charles describes their appearance as "crimped and frizzed in scarves and earrings and perfume and long white gloves like Mother or in claw-hammer coats and boiled shirts and white ties and yesterday's haircuts like Father and Uncle Gavin" (75-76). Many were reluctant to include Eula and Flem Snopes on the list of invitees; during the ball, they are described as aghast at the way Manfred de Spain and Eula Varner Snopes dance together with "splendid unshame" (79).
These unnamed "loafers, Negro and white boys too," watch the Cotillion couples arrive at the Opera House (76).

The famous band leader and composer "from Beale Street in Memphis" W.C. Handy provides the music for the Cotillion Ball (76). The novel calls him "Professor Handy" (76); another title for him, the one he gave himself, was 'Father of the Blues."

CharacterName: Unnamed Two Men at the Cotillion Ball
Biography: These two men attempt to help Gavin Stevens arise after Manfred de Spain has struck him down (79).
Sort Name: Unnamed Two Men at the Cotillion Ball
CharacterKey: Unnamed Two Men at the Cotillion Ball

Biography: Sally Priest's husband, Maurice, fights with Grenier Weddel and blacks one of his eyes for sending his wife "not just what Father called a standard panic-size corsage, but a triple one" (81). Then, at home, Maurice Priest blackens his wife's eye. (The Maury Priest who appears in The Reivers is apparently a different character.)

The first Snopes in Jefferson was Mink, one of Flem's many relatives, who "spent two and a half months in the Jefferson jail on his way to his permanent residence in the penitentiary at Parchman for killing Zack Houston" (82). He becomes a major figure in the final volume of the Snopes trilogy.
OtherTexts: The Hamlet, The Mansion, The Reivers

Biography: Schoolteacher Letty Bookright married Zack Houston with her father's reluctant consent. Less than a year after their marriage, Letty was killed by Houston's prized stallion (82).

FirstAppearence: Bottom and Slough in Frenchman's Bend
