She hides his misdoings from their father, and she cries when Rodney asks her for two thousand dollars to cover his theft from the Compress Association: "Aunt Louisa begged Mr. Pruitt for Grandpa's sake and . . . gave Mr. Pruitt her oath that Uncle Rodney would stay right there in the house until papa could get there, and Mr. Pruitt said how he hated it to happen at Christmas too and so for Grandpa's and Aunt Louisa's sake he would give them until the day after Christmas if Aunt Louisa would promise him that Uncle Rodney would not try to leave Mottstown" (271).

In "That Will Be Fine," this is the Fred who is Georgie's uncle and Aunt Louisa's husband; he lives with his wife's parents in Mottstown. Fred is aware of Rodney's crimes but unable to do much about them.
The narrator's cousin Louisa is the young daughter of Aunt Louisa and Uncle Fred.
Cousin Fred is the young son of Aunt Louisa and Uncle Fred.
This is the youngest child of Uncle Fred and Aunt Louisa. Georgie's narrative does provide either its name or its gender.

He is the husband of Rodney's earlier Jefferson conquest, Mrs. Tucker. Rodney makes clear to Georgie, the story's very young and uncomprehending narrator, that Mr. Tucker is not involved in the "business" he does with Mrs. Tucker while Georgie watches for her husband outside the Tucker house (268).

John Paul is the servant who drives the hack for Georgie's family and is willing to speak sarcastically about Uncle Rodney's behavior. He is observant and witty: "John Paul said he bet papa would like to give Uncle Rodney a present without even waiting for Christmas . . . a job of work"; "John Paul quit laughing and said Sho, he reckoned anything a man kept at all the time, night and day both, he would call it work no matter how much fun it started out to be" (270). When Georgie asserts that Uncle Rodney now works for the Compress Association, John Paul says "it would sholy take a whole association to compress Uncle Rodney" (270).

Mr. Pruitt is President of the Compress Association and a recent arrival in Mottstown. He discovers Rodney's theft of the bonds and forgery of Grandpa's check. He seems like a decent man, if one as yet unfamiliar with extent of Rodney's duplicity, when he agrees in the spirit of Christmas to give Rodney's family more time to replace the money. But if, as is most likely, he is also the "man" who later catches his wife planning to run away with Rodney and decides to use her and "the jewelry" to bait a trap for him (283), it's clear that there are limits to his kindness.

The unnamed sheriff of the county that includes Mottstown in "That Will Be Fine" is going to question Uncle Rodney about the bond theft and forgery. He later watches for Uncle Rodney's attempt to abscond with Grandpa's neighbor's wife and "all the jewelry" (281).
After Mrs. Church pays a call on Mrs. Pruitt, she gossips about her with the women of Grandpa's family, saying that she uses too much makeup, does not dress properly, and drinks.

The wife of the President of the Compress Association in Mottstown is having an affair with Rodney, the uncle of the story's narrator. According to gossip, Mrs. Pruitt would have been an easy conquest for Rodney. However, Rodney's sisters Louisa and Sarah claim that their brother was led astray by Mrs. Pruitt. Their opinion perhaps says more about them than about her, but at least according to Louisa, Mrs. Pruitt is a "Painted common thing, traipsing up and down the streets all afternoon alone in a buggy, and the one and only time Mrs. Church called on her, and that was because of Mr. Pruitt's position alone, Mrs. Church found her without corsets on and Mrs. Church told me she smelled liquor on her breath'" (274).
Mandy cooks for Grandpa, but she seems to have disappeared the day before Christmas, missing her duties as cook and leaving her cabin mysteriously "locked on the inside" (274).

Emmeline is the nursemaid for Aunt Louisa's baby. She takes Mandy's place in cooking breakfast, complaining "that she was going to waste all her Christmas doing extra work they never had the sense she give them credit for and that this looked like to her it was a good house to be away from nohow" (279).
Mrs. Jordon is Grandpa's Mottstown neighbor in "That Will Be Fine"; at the end of the story, after Rodney is killed, Rosie is taking Georgie to her house for the night.
Georgie sees these "ladies with shawls over their heads" arriving at his grandparents' house to offer their condolences to Rodney's family (286).
These Mottstown men carry Rodney's body; Georgie says, "I could look back and see the six men in the moonlight carrying the blind with the bundle on it" (286).

These two men prevent Georgie from seeing his uncle's corpse. One of these men picks up Georgie and carries him away. This man has a sense of irony worthy of Faulkner himself. When Georgie naively asks if the "wrapped bundle" that other men are carrying (Rodney's corpse, "wrapped in a quilt" and laid on a shutter) is "a Christmas present for Grandpa," this man replies yes, "From all the husbands in Mottstown" (286).

The older of the two men who discover Lonnie's body is described as "a man of about forty" (72); his dialect - "Him and Joe" (67), "Yonder's his boat" (69) - indicates that, like most of the story's characters, he's a "country-bred man" (78).

The younger of the two men who discover Lonnie's body is described as "a youth, less than twenty, by his face" (67). He tells Stevens that, after the discovery, he "won't never eat another" fish (74).

Lonnie Grinnup was christened Louis Grenier. He was the last descendant of one of the three white men who founded Yoknapatawpha County "a hundred years" earlier (70). He's "a man a little under medium size and somewhere in his middle thirties" (70). He has lived for decades in a shack on the river, "in almost the exact center" of the huge plantation once owned by the ancestor for whom he was named, though Lonnie himself was unaware of both that past and his own true name. He was seriously handicapped mentally, but generous, "pleasant, equable," willing to share the little he has with anyone and a devoted foster "brother and father" to the man named Joe (71).

Joe is “a man not large, but with tremendous arms and shoulders; an adult, yet with something childlike about him” (68). Like Lonnie Grinnup, Joe has severe mental disabilities, being “deaf and dumb” (68). Joe, an “orphan” (70, 71), was “adopted” by Lonnie Grinnup, to whom he is fiercely loyal.

Gavin Stevens, the county attorney, is the last representative of the pioneers who founded Yoknapatawpha County. Lonnie Grinnup had been the other living representative. Stevens goes "to look at the dead man’s face for a sentimental reason" (70). That sentiment initiates the Lonnie Grinnup murder case, because at the inquest for Lonnie Stevens smells something fishy. In his own way, which has clear connections to the traditions of literary detectives but also to the aristocratic idea of "noblesse oblige," Stevens proceeds to solve the mystery of Lonnie's death.
OtherTexts: "A Name for the City", "An Error in Chemistry", "By the People", "Go Down, Moses", "Hair", "Knight's Gambit", "Monk", "Smoke", "Tomorrow", Go Down, Moses, Intruder in the Dust, Light in August, Requiem for a Nun, The Mansion, The Town

Biography: The coroner who contacts Stevens about Lonnie Grinnup’s death and presides over the inquest is described as "an old country doctor" (70). He signs the death certificate without ever suspecting the death might not have been an accident.

FirstAppearence: Road Between Jefferson and Frenchman's Bend
Biography: One of the founders of Yoknapatawpha County was a man named "Stevens" (70). Together with two others named Holston and Grenier, he came "on horseback, through the Cumberland Gap from the Carolinas," bought land from the Indians, established a family and "flourished" (70). Though the text gives no idea how he prospered, he is referred to as the only one of these founding fathers with a living descendant who bears his name.
OtherTexts: "A Rose for Emily", Light in August

Biography: One of the founders of Yoknapatawpha County was a man named "Holston" (70). Together with two others named Stevens and Grenier, he came "on horseback, through the Cumberland Gap from the Carolinas," bought land from the Indians, established a family and "flourished" (70). In other Yoknapatawpha fictions he opens Jefferson's first hotel, the Holston House, which survives into the 20th century. This story, however, does not give any indication of how he prospered, and says that in time he "vanished" (70).
OtherTexts: Intruder in the Dust, Requiem for a Nun, The Mansion, The Town

FirstAppearence: Road Between Jefferson and Frenchman's Bend
Biography: One of the founders of Yoknapatawpha County was a man named Grenier. Together with two others named Stevens and Holston, he came "on horseback, through the Cumberland Gap from the Carolinas," bought land from the Indians, established a family and "flourished" (70). In fact, before the Civil War he owned a plantation with a "thousand and more acres" of land (71), and in other Yoknapatawpha fictions is identified as Louis Grenier, the original "Old Frenchman" after whom Frenchman's Bend is named.
OtherTexts: "A Name for the City", "Lizards in Jamshyd’s Courtyard", Intruder in the Dust, Requiem for a Nun, Sanctuary, The Hamlet, The Reivers , The Town

Biography: The eldest of the four men - the others are Pose, Matthew, and Jim Blake - who load Lonnie Grinnup’s body onto a wagon for transfer to Tyler Ballenbaugh’s truck.
One of the four men - the others are Ike, Matthew, and Jim Blake - who load Lonnie Grinnup’s body onto a wagon for transfer to Tyler Ballenbaugh’s truck in "Hand upon the Waters."
One of the four men - the others are Ike, Pose, and Jim Blake - who load Lonnie Grinnup’s body onto a wagon for transfer to Tyler Ballenbaugh’s truck in "Hand upon the Waters."
One of the four men - the others are Ike, Pose, and Matthew - who load Lonnie Grinnup’s body onto a wagon for transfer to Tyler Ballenbaugh’s truck.

Tyler Ballenbaugh is "a farmer, married and with a family and a reputation for self-sufficiency and violence," and for having won large "sums" as a gambler (75). That reputation returns with him from the time he spent "out West" (75). After his return to Yoknapatawpha, he continues to gamble, by speculating in "cotton futures" and even betting on Lonnie's Grinnup's life expectancy (75). He is cool and levelheaded in comparison with his younger brother Boyd.

Boyd Ballenbaugh is Tyler Ballenbaugh’s younger brother. After a brief career in Memphis, where he worked as a hired guard during an industrial dispute and then got involved in undisclosed but apparently criminal activities with a set of "associates," he returns to his brother's house in Yoknapatawpha to hide out (76). A drunkard and a braggart, he is hotheaded and violent. Because he resents having to work for his brother "about the farm" (76), he comes up with what he thinks will be a quick - and murderous - way to make money.

The insurance company doctor who examines Lonnie Grinnup in Mottstown "had never seen Lonnie Grinnup before, but he had known Tyler Ballenbaugh for years," and so has no qualms about qualifying Lonnie for the policy that Tyler pays for (77).
This agent for the insurance company that issued the policy on Lonnie's life willingly follows Gavin Stevens’s instructions to help capture his killer.

At the end of the story "the sheriff of the county" visits Stevens to wrap up the details of Stevens' unofficial investigation. He tries to get Stevens to confirm that Joe murdered Boyd Ballenbaugh. Stevens does not take the bait.

A Negro farmer who lives in a cabin near the path to Lonnie's camp, and the owner of the "Negro voice" that "answers" Stevens when he asks him to let people at the nearby store know if he, Stevens, isn't "back by daylight" (79). In response to his wife's misgivings, Nate "murmurs something" - but readers never hear what Nate himself says, either to Stevens or to her (80).

Nate's wife appears in the novel only as another voice in the darkness at their cabin, when readers hear her telling her husband to "let them white folks alone" (80) - suggesting she has more authority over Nate than Gavin Stevens does.

Ike tells Stevens that Lonnie Grinnup had saved his "burying money" with Mitchell "at the store" (73). It's clear that the money is for his funeral expenses, but not clear who "Mitchell" is in this context. He could be the store owner (though in all the other fictions where the Frenchman's Bend store occurs, it is owned by the Varners), or - as seems more likely - Mitchell is a local undertaker, whose clients put money away for him at the store, which thus functions as a kind of bank for the people who live outside the town.

CharacterName: Unnamed Friends and Associates of Boyd Ballenbaugh
Biography: For the last few years, Boyd Ballenbaugh has been hiding at his brother’s, "not from the police but from some of his Memphis friends or later business associates" (76). Both the mention of the police and the fact that Boyd is in hiding seems to suggest that, like many of the characters whom Faulkner's fictions locate in Memphis, these men are members of the underworld, and their "business" some kind of criminal activity - but that is not made explicit.
Sort Name: Unnamed Friends and Associates of Boyd Ballenbaugh
CharacterKey: Unnamed Friends and Associates of Boyd Ballenbaugh

Biography: Boyd Ballenbaugh "was subdued and thrown into jail once by two officers in Jefferson" (76).
Judge Allison's father-in-law was "a Republican" with whose politics the Judge agrees (789). Politically, Allison and his father-in-law are very much in the minority in Yoknapatawpha.

Judge Allison mentions the "extra groom" who went with the Allison family when they rode to church in order to tend his son's pony while they were in services (790). "Groom" here means a person employed to take care of horses.

Joel Flint used to work in carnivals. At one point he was known as Signor Canova, a master of illusion. After abandoning the Canova persona, Flint started working in other circuses, serving as "bandsman, ringman, Bornean wild man" (134). Eventually, his role in traveling carnivals was as a pitch man with a "roulette wheel wired against imitation watches and pistols which would not shoot" (134). His carnival came to Yoknapatawpha County, and when the show packed up and left, Flint stayed on and married Ellie Pritchell, the "dim-witted spinster" daughter of misanthrope Wesley Prichell (113). Due to his circus experience, Flint is a master of disguise; he is also fearless, a killer, and vain enough to think he is smarter than everyone else.

The sheriff of Yoknapatawpha in this story has the first name "Hub." He isn't given a last name, but it's very likely that he is one of the three Hampton's who serve as county sheriff in the fictions - one of the two nicknamed Hub (short for Hubert) - and the Hub Hampton who also appears in Intruder in the Dust (1948), The Town (1957) and The Mansion (1960). A friend of Gavin Stevens, he is described as "a big man with little hard eyes" (116). He has been the sheriff "off and on" for quite a while and likes to quote the Bible when talking with Gavin (115). According to the narrator, the Sheriff speaks and moves "with that deliberate, slightly florid, old-fashioned courtesy which only big men can wear, except that his was constant" (128).
OtherTexts: Intruder in the Dust, The Mansion, The Town

Biography: Wesley Pritchel owns a small farm. He is unhappy when his "dim-witted spinster" daughter, Ellie, marries Joel Flint, a carnival pitch man (113). Pritchel is irascible and likes to be left alone. He is murdered by Joel Flint.

The story never gives a name to the person who narrates it, though we can say for sure that he is a nephew of Gavin Stevens, whom he repeatedly calls "Uncle Gavin" (115, etc.). In the context of Faulkner's other fictions, this is enough to identify him as Charles "Chick" Mallison, Gavin's only nephew and a narrator in a number of other texts, including two other tales in Knight's Gambit. The narrator says little about himself; he lives in the house his grandfather and father lived in, though both men have died, and he clearly thinks of Gavin as a kind of surrogate father. He is referred to as "boy" by Joel Flint while disguised as Wesley Pritchel (131), but earlier in the story he describes himself being "supervised" by his Uncle "in the drawing of a brief" (115), which implies that he is a law student or a young lawyer.
OtherTexts: "By the People", "Monk", "Tomorrow", Intruder in the Dust, The Mansion, The Town
social_status: has influential social contacts (family, business, political)

Biography: This entry represents the various unnamed neighbors of Wesley Pritchel, the "people in the adjacent countryside" (119). It is safe to assume that they are all, like Pritchel himself, farming families. They play several different roles in the story. They gossip about Wesley's relationship with his "son-in-law" (114). Until Pritchel's drives them off, they take clay from his clay-pit to make "serviceable though crude pottery" (119). The "man and his wife" who are Pritchel's "nearest neighbors" are summoned to his house by the sheriff to stay with the old man after Ellie's murder (118). This couple is soon joined by "other neighbors," all of whom stay at Pritchel's house even though he yells at them to leave (118). They return to the house for Ellie's funeral, when a "meagre group" of them attend the burial (125) and "two neighbor women" cook a hot meal for him (124).

"Generations" of these "random boys" dug into the clay-pit on Wesley Pritchel's farm, where they found "Indian and even aboriginal relics - flint arrow-heads, axes and dishes ad skulls and thigh-bones and pipes" (119).
These three men from an unidentified place in the North want to buy Wesley Pritchel's farm in order to use the clay from the clay-pit to "manufacture some kind of road material" (119).

Ben Berry is a Deputy Sheriff. Sheriff Hub sends him to keep an eye on the Flints' house in case Joel Flint returns there after escaping from the local jail cell. He loses his "spectacles in the woods" during the pursuit, and so can't read an important clue to the killer's identity (123).

A "stranger" in "neat city clothes" (126), Mr. Workman is an insurance adjuster from the Memphis office of the company that wrote a life insurance policy on Ellie. He speaks with a "cold" voice, yet is described as being in "a sort of seething boil" about the shooting (126). Suspecting something after meeting with "Old Man Pritchel" in person (126), he goes out of his way to tell the sheriff about the imminent sale of the Pritchel farm.
The unnamed wife of Wesley Pritchel was the mother of four children. She is already dead when "An Error in Chemistry" begins.
Gavin Stevens' father is also the grandfather of the narrator of "An Error in Chemistry." Gavin Stevens' father liked to drink cold toddies with friends who would come over to his house.
OtherTexts: "A Rose for Emily", "Tomorrow", The Mansion, The Reivers , The Town
social_status: has influential social contacts (family, business, political)

Biography: Unnamed men who came to the narrator's grandfather's house (Gavin Stevens' father's house) to socialize and drink cold toddies.

The "governor" of South Carolina when it became the first state to secede from the Union, occupied Fort Moultrie and "refused to surrender it" (11), and began the Civil War by attacking Fort Sumter, was Frances Pickens; descended from a famous Carolina family, he strongly supported the creation and the cause of the Confederacy.

These unnamed local residents are people Joel Flint meets and talks with most often "in the little cross-road hamlet near his home" and occasionally in "Jefferson" (114). Nothing specific is known about these unnamed people except that they find Flint contemptuous of their custom for drinking whiskey with sugar and water.

The sheriff sends "Ben Berry and some others" to Joel Flint's house in case the escaped Joel Flint returns there (122). These "others" are not described in any way, though it seems as if they are not members of the sheriff's office, which is why we identify them as a kind of 'posse.'
There is no biographical information about the unnamed jailer who appears in this story. In the narrative he discovers that Flint has somehow escaped from his cell without leaving a trace.

John Sartoris' sister Jenny refers elliptically to the "better colonel" whom the men of the Confederate regiment from Yoknapatawpha elected to replace him as their commander early in the war (238). Later in his career Faulkner will give this figure a name - Thomas Sutpen, the central character of Absalom, Absalom (1936).

CharacterName: Unnamed Young Woman in Mount Vernon
Biography: This "young woman" is only mentioned once, as the person with whom Lee MacCallum is "keeping company" (i.e. courting, 350).
Sort Name: Unnamed Young Woman in Mount Vernon

CharacterName: Unnamed Man Who Wrote Little Women Books
Biography: While telling Judge Allison whom he might expect to meet in other parts of Beyond, Mothershed mentions "the one that wrote the little women books. If he ain't there, he ought to be" (788). The book title 'Little Women' was of course not written by a man, and the story doesn't give any further information about the person Mothershed is thinking of. One possibility is Edward Stratemeyer (1863-1930), who wrote books under pseudonyms for boys as well as girls, but there's no way to say if Faulkner is even thinking about an actual children's book author. Because Mothershed says he is in Beyond, however, he is a character in the story, regardless of his existence anywhere else.
Sort Name: Unnamed Man Who Wrote Little Women Books
CharacterKey: Unnamed Man Who Wrote Little Women Books

Biography: When he returns to Yoknapatawpha from Beyond, still unable to accept his death, the judge thinks about "the neighbors" who will see his "clocklike passing" as he walks home at the same time he used to (795).
Georgie's mother theorizes that "most other men were prejudiced against Uncle Rodney, why she didn't know" (267).
This is the "other lady in Mottstown" who - according to the account of the story's very young narrator - had "business" with Rodney, though "just one time" (268).

The boys and girls who are Minnie Cooper's "contemporaries" and "schoolmates" begin to ostracize her before they are finished with high school, apparently because her "people," while "comfortable," are "not the best" people (174). They grow up to marry and have their own families, leaving Minnie on the sidelines of the town's life.

The man with the badge outside Grandpa's house in Mottstown reminds Georgie of "Mr. Watts at Jefferson that catches the niggers," so it seems certain that Watts is either the sheriff or one of the deputies or, perhaps, the town marshal (277). The fact that all the people he catches are black probably reflects the fact that most arrested people in Faulkner's Yoknapatawpha are black, not that Watts has a special commission to catch blacks.

This icon represents the "man on the kitchen roof" who gave Minnie Cooper a "man scare" by spying on her while she undressed for bed (171). Although he may have actually existed, the context suggests that the man in the barber shop who recounts this event believes she made him up. We have labeled him "white" because from the larger story it seems clear that if the reported voyeur had been identified as "black," the white men of the town would have had to punish someone.
Ontological Status: Created by a Character in Text

Biography: The narrator refers to "the Jew owners of Chicago and New York sweatshops," who manufacture the "fine bright cheap intransigent clothes" that TP wears (343). The assumption that owners of garment factories would be Jewish and the designation of those factories as "sweatshops" indicate a streak of antisemitism that sounds more in line with the voice of Jason Compson IV in 1929 than Faulkner's post-WWII narrator in the "Appendix."

Although Jason Compson IV's entry in "Appendix Compson" refers dismissively to the police as not deserving his fear and respect (338), it does turn to "consider" the police repeatedly (338, 342). Jason cannot claim the help of the police without admitting more of his affairs than he cares to, and yet he chafes at paying for a police force that is characterized as existing in "parasitic and sadistic idleness" (342).

The bondsmen to whom Jason Compson IV refers appear to monitor Jason's role as "guardian and trustee" (342). Jason is, presumably, guardian of Caddy's daughter, Quentin Compson, and entrusted with the finances of the Compson estate.
The district Chancellor receives Jason Compson IV's financial reports each year.
This is the "paw" who "ought" to have "burned" his son's "britches off" for being out in the early morning hours to witness the robbery of the Christian's Drugstore (61).

Ratliff speculates that Flem has "spies" that watch Montgomery Ward's business. He imagines them as children, moreover, "since any little child hired with a ice cream cone" would suit Flem's needs (62).
Ontological Status: Created by a Character in Text

Biography: The "humanbeings swinging golfsticks" walk a course on land that was previously owned by the Compsons (340).

Maury is the "only brother" of the Compson children's mother (340). Although she attempts to honor him by making her youngest son his namesake, Maury seems far from honorable: "a handsome flashing swaggering workless bachelor who borrowed money from almost anyone" (340).

In this novel "Mrs. Littlejohn" is only mentioned as Bryon Snopes passes through Frenchman's Bend on his way out of Yoknapatawpha; he notices her "huge, unpainted boarding house" as he drives by it (278).
OtherTexts: "Lizards in Jamshyd’s Courtyard", "Spotted Horses", The Hamlet, The Town

Biography: These are the local Yoknapatawpha men who own the "topless and battered cars, the saddled horses and mules and the wagons, the riders and drivers of which" Gavin Stevens knows by name (72). The men show up to Lonnie Grinnup's inquest in their "clean Saturday overalls and shirts and the bared heads and the sunburned necks striped with the white razor lines of Saturday neck shaves" (72). Among these men are the "folks" who go out to view Grinnup's camp and trotline later and see Joe hanging about (77).
Houston's neighbors "didn't dare knock on his door anymore" after his wife died (8).
After planting their cotton fields, the "overalled men" of Frenchman's Bend regularly gather at Varner's store, to "squat or stand all day against the front wall or inside the store itself" (29).

While she is at college in Oxford, Linda employs this lawyer to draw up a will for her that will transfer her share of the Varner estate to Flem Snopes. This lawyer is given a name in The Town, and the name is that of one of Faulkner's lifelong friends, "[Phil] Stone," the Oxford lawyer to whom all three volumes of the Snopes trilogy are dedicated.
Mink has "companions of his age and sex" who go with him to Memphis brothels (36).

The unnamed president of the "old bank, the Bank of Jefferson" is later called Grandfather Lucius Priest in The Reivers. This connection is made explicit by the fact that this unnamed bank president and Grandfather Lucius Priest both own a "White Steamer" - an early make of automobile produced by the White Motor Company (37).
social_status: has influential social contacts (family, business, political)

FirstAppearence: Road Between Jefferson and Frenchman's Bend
Biography: On his way to jail Mink imagines that Flem has sent a messenger to reach out to him and help him somehow.
Ontological Status: Created by a Character in Text

Biography: According to the narrative, "the last of the Holston family" - one of the three first (white) families in Yoknapatawpha - died "before the end of the last century," i.e. sometime before 1900 (70). This story does not connect the family to the Holston House, the Jefferson hotel that survives into the 20th century.

These "dozen trusties" in the Parchman penitentiary are not described in any detail (74), but "trusty" is the generic term for prison inmates who can be trusted to help the authorities administer the institution. They are typically given (minor) privileges and allowed (limited) freedoms that other inmates aren't. Montgomery Ward Snopes assumes Flem could bribe one of them to kill Mink for "ten grand" - ten thousand dollars (74).
Tyler Ballenbaugh's "family" is mentioned when he first appears in the story, but no other details about them are given (75).

Someone informs Stevens about both Lonnie's funeral and Joe's whereabouts on the day he was buried. There is good reason to think this person is someone from Frenchman's Bend, and it may even be the coroner whose telephone call first brought Stevens into the story, but all the text provides is a voice which speaks in correct (i.e. not vernacular) English and with unmistakable if unsentimental sympathy for Joe's loss.

Montgomery Ward refers to this girl when, in a passage summing up the scoundrels in his family, he talks about "Uncle Wesley leading a hymn with one hand and fumbling the skirt of an eleven-year-old infant with the other" (93). In The Town Wesley is caught having sex with a fourteen-year-old, so it is certainly possible that Monty is referring to a real event and victim, but it seems more probable that, as in his use of the word "infant," Monty is inventing or exaggerating here. (The 'Unnamed Fourteen-Year-Old Girl' in the earlier novel has her own character entry.)
Ontological Status: Created by a Character in Text

Biography: These "young fellers from the paper" who report the story of Mink Snopes' attempted prison break repeatedly ask him what his real name is, since "Mink" is "jest a nickname" (98).

FirstAppearence: Western Front Inset: On the Road to Amiens
Biography: Comyn, a native of Ireland and a Royal Flying Corps pilot, is among those who go to the Cloche-Clos in Amiens to celebrate the end of the war. Proud of his Irish background, he disdains the English nation he has served. He is drinking heavily and looking for women or a fight or both.

FirstAppearence: Western Front Inset: On the Road to Amiens
Biography: The American southerner named simply "Sartoris" in "Ad Astra" is Bayard Sartoris, one of the major characters in Faulkner's first Yoknapatawpha novel, Flags in the Dust (1929); there his inability to get over the death of his twin brother, described briefly in this story, symbolizes his membership in a lost generation. Like the other central characters in the story, Sartoris is a pilot in the Royal Flying Corps. He "never did talk much; just did his patrols and maybe once a week he'd sit and drink his nostrils white in a quiet sort of way" (414). After he avenges his twin brother's death in air combat, he seems more concerned with drinking than with speaking or fighting.
OtherTexts: "There Was a Queen", Flags in the Dust, Sanctuary, The Mansion, The Town

FirstAppearence: Western Front Inset: Skies over France
Biography: The Sartoris who appears in this story has a twin brother who is killed in July, 1918, four months before the end of the War. In Faulkner's first Yoknapatawpha novel, Flags in the Dust (1929), he is named Johnny, and his death in the air over France is perhaps the novel's most important event. As the novel describes in more detail, in the story his death is soon avenged by his brother (414).
OtherTexts: "All the Dead Pilots", "There Was a Queen", "With Caution and Dispatch", Flags in the Dust, The Mansion

FirstAppearence: Western Front Inset: On the Road to Amiens
Biography: Identified as "a Southerner" (408), before the War Bland went to England as a Rhodes scholar. During the War he serves as an Royal Flying Corps pilot, though "in the five months he had been out, no one had ever found a bullet hole in his machine" - suggesting that he was choosing not to engage in combat (408). Drinking with the other officers, Bland likes to talk about his imaginary wife. This "Bland" is probably the same person who appears In The Sound and the Fury as Gerald Bland, one of Quentin Compson's Harvard contemporaries, who is preoccupied with conquests of women.

FirstAppearence: Western Front Inset: On the Road to Amiens
Biography: Monaghan, a Lieutenant in the Royal Flying Corps, describes himself as "shanty Irish," because his late father made "a million dollars digging sewers in the ground" (414). He is also a former student at Yale. Monaghan seems uncomfortable with his complex social status, and there is "something of the crucified" about him after three years of war (414). When peace is declared, he removes his uniform insignia: "I don't know what I am. I have been in this damn war for three years and all I know is, I'm not dead" (415). Monaghan stays very close to the captured German officer, whom he shot down earlier in the day and claims that he will take back to America. He also recalls this evening's events in Flags in the Dust (1929) and in Faulkner's non-Yoknapatawpha short story, "Honor" (1931). Faulkner also remembered Monaghan many years later, writing him into A Fable (1954).

Franz is the elder of a pair of twins who are younger brothers to the captured German officer. When his older brother refuses to become baron, Franz, as next in line, is passed over because he is already committed to the career of a military officer. Franz becomes baron designate when the younger twin is killed in Berlin by a jealous husband. Franz progresses through the ranks from colonel to "general of staff" (419), but near the end of the War is assassinated by a German soldier in Berlin.
The character in "Ad Astra" named Hume is probably another Allied aviator, but in the story his role is to narrate the way Sartoris managed to avenge his brother's death.

FirstAppearence: Western Front Inset: On the Road to Amiens
Biography: Writing "twelve years" after November 11, 1918, the unnamed narrator served during the War as an American flying in a British squadron (408). In his only explicit references to himself, he talks about the "pleasant" but tense feeling that precedes the moment "in combat" when "you know something is about to happen" (421). Until the last pages of the story he remains a silent witness to the events, but he reports what the others say and do clearly and without bias. He agrees to write the wounded German aviator's wife. When Comyn and Monaghan escort their prisoner into an Amiens brothel, Bland asks the narrator if they will "Prop him in the corner and turn the light off? Or do French brothels have he-beds too?" (427). The narrator clearly dismisses Bland's question and the complex of assumptions it implies: "Who the hell's business is that?" (427). He is an extraordinarily intelligent, articulate, and objective reporter. Recalling the Indian subadar's assertion that "all men are brothers," the narrator thinks of the entire group "as bugs in the surface of the water, isolant and aimless and unflagging" (408).

FirstAppearence: Western Front Inset: On the Road to Amiens
Biography: Bandaged and "sick," the German pilot whom Monaghan has shot down on the day Germany surrenders is nonetheless described as wearing the appearance of "a man who has conquered himself" (412). Born into a noble family in Prussia as the oldest of four brothers, he repudiated his hereditary title. He studies music at the university in Bayreuth, marries a woman beneath his privileged class, and fathers a child with her. Over time, however, the loss of each of his three younger brothers sends him back to military service. On the morning of November 11, his mother writes him with the news that his youngest brother has been assassinated and he himself is now the Baron. He attempts to escape that, but his suicidal final flight fails when he survives the crash of his plane. He remains philosophical about his own and Germany's defeats. In his conversations with the subadar, he offers the idea that his break with his family tradition is a significant gesture towards brotherhood, but he himself becomes the object of a barroom brawl when his captors insist on displaying him to the local French.

The third child of the German family (and a younger brother of the German prisoner) is the twin of Franz. He shows no obligation to serve his family, and according to his oldest brother, he "did nothing in Berlin" (417). Although he comes home to be assume the title of Baron, his brother continues: "he does not stay at home. In 1912 he iss in Berlin newspaper dead of a lady's husband" (418). It seems likely that the "lady" is this man's mistress.

FirstAppearence: Western Front Inset: On the Road to Amiens
Biography: At the time of the story, 'subadar' was a rank roughly equivalent to captain, given to Indian nationals who led Indian troops as part of the English armed forces. The subadar in "Ad Astra" identifies himself as a "prince" in India, "my country" (408). Before the War, Bland saw him deliver a speech in Oxford, England, a time when the subadar himself says "I was a white man also for that moment" (409). In France he is attached to a battalion of Indian soldiers who serve the British military, probably by relaying British orders to them. He is well-educated, egalitarian, opposed to warfare and the authorities who insist upon it, and prepared to live as "an exile" afterward (427). On the evening of November 11, 1918, he seems to sum up Faulkner's story when he says: "What will any of us do? All this generation which fought in the war are dead tonight. But we do not yet know it" (421). Like the German prisoner, the subadar asserts "I too will not be baron" by declining to accept the responsibilities of his caste; he says: "I undid in one day what it took two thousand years to do. Is not that something?" (427). He insists to his companions of the evening that "this life is nothing" (417).

CharacterName: Unnamed Youngest Brother of German Prisoner
Biography: The youngest of four German brothers flourishes in the German military service, beginning as a "cadet of dragoons" (417) and eventually becoming an aviator. When his eldest brother last sees him, he "iss now ace with iron cross by the kaiser's own hand" (419). In 1916, he is shot down by the Canadian air ace Bishop.
Sort Name: Unnamed Youngest Brother of German Prisoner
CharacterKey: Unnamed Youngest Brother of German Prisoner

Biography: The mother of the German prisoner in "Ad Astra" is at times distant from her eldest son, because of her husband's disapproval. After her husband's death, she informs this son of developments within the family. Very shortly before the day of the story, she writes again to inform him that since his last living brother is dead, he must be assume the title of Baron after all.

The captured aviator's father is a nobleman - as he puts it, "my people are of Prussia little barons" - who does not approve when his eldest son renounces the title of "baron" (417). The father dies during the War of natural causes.

As an American military policeman (A.M.P.), this unnamed character competes with Monaghan for control over the German prisoner. Mystified by the company of headstrong and independent aviators in which he finds himself, he insultingly asserts his authority over the French officer at the Cloche-Clos in Amiens, thus helping to bring on the riot. The French officer calls him a "devil-dog" - a World War I era slang term for a U.S. Marine (422).

The waiter at the Cloche-Clos is "an old man in a dirty apron"; when he notices the German prisoner in the bistro, he falls "back before us, slack-jawed, with an expression of outraged unbelief, like an atheist confronted with either Christ or the devil" (411). The last we see of him is amidst the chaos of the brawl that breaks out; at its climax, Comyn is seen carrying or dragging this "ancient waiter" "beneath his arm" (424).

The patronne is the manager and owner of the Cloche-Clos. An old woman who wears steel spectacles and knits, she thoroughly understands the threat posed to her business by the Allied aviators and their German prisoner. She loudly expresses her outrage that this German - whom she calls a "Boche!" (422) - has been brought into her bistro: "Eight months since the obus I have kept them in a box against this day: plates, cups, saucers, glasses, all that I have had since thirty years, all gone, broken at one time! And it costing me fifty centimes the glass for such that I shame myself to have my patrons - " (422). (Obus is French for artillery shell; it seems she uses the term to refer to the time, eight months earlier, when the Germans began bombarding Amiens, and a shell destroyed the tools of her trade.)

In the Cloche-Close, a French officer, "tall, with a gaunt, tragic face," implies that Monaghan and the military policeman should remove the German prisoner from the premises (422). The officer has a glass eye, probably as a result of the war; it is described as "motionless, rigid in a face that looked even deader than the spurious eye" (422).

FirstAppearence: Western Front Inset: On the Road to Amiens
Biography: Bland has apparently invented an imaginary wife for his own neurotic reasons. The narrator reports "when [Bland] was tight he would talk about his wife, though we all knew that he was not married" (408). In the story's last line, he refers to her as his "poor little wife" (429).
Ontological Status: Created by a Character in Text

Biography: An immigrant to the U.S., Monaghan's father brags about his "Shanty Irish" origins, but at the time of the story, he is a self-made millionaire who began his rise to wealth by collecting refuse and finally by building municipal sewage systems. Monaghan quotes him: "When you're with your fine friends, the fathers and mothers and sisters of them you met at Yale, ye might just remind them that every man is the slave of his own refuse and so your old dad they would be sending around to the forty-story back doors of their kitchens is the king of them all" (415).

This is one of Faulkner's characters who are defined by absence and indeterminacy. When the aviator Monaghan explains his "Shanty Irish" origins, he gives a memorable description of his father, but he cannot trace his ancestry before that: other than saying his father came "out of a peat bog," which suggests the Irish peasantry, Monaghan claims, "I don’t know what my grandfather was. I don’t know if I had one. My father don’t remember one. Likely it could have been one of several" (415).

The "damned king" of England whom Monaghan refers to contemptuously and whom the Irish Comyn denies is "his damned king" was George V (416). King George V ruled the United Kingdom from 1910 to 1936. He was also Emperor of India during this period.

The "kaiser" whom the German aviator refers to without naming is Kaiser Wilhelm II (Friedrich Wilhelm Victor Albert von Hohenzollern); he ruled Germany as emperor from June 1888 to November 9, 1918. On that date, having lost the support of the army, he abdicated, and fled the country a day later. The German prisoner says he does not serve "baron and kaiser" (418), but he is proud when his brother Franz is declared "ace iron cross by the kaiser's own hand" (419).
The man the American M.P. refers to simply as "your president" when he's arguing with the French officer is Raymond Poincare, who was President of France during World War I.

William Avery Bishop (1894-1956) led all Canadian aviators during World War I, being credited with shooting down 72 German planes. The captive German aviator of "Ad Astra" reports that one of his younger brothers, and already an ace aviator himself, "iss killed by your Bishop . . . that good man" (419).

Two military mechanics were required to "shoehorn" the exceptionally large Comyn "into the cockpit of a Dolphin, like two chambermaids putting an emergency bolster into a case too large for it" (410). (The Sopwith Dolphin was one of the standard British fighter planes during the First World War.)

CharacterName: Unnamed Friends and Acquaintances of Monaghan
Biography: Monaghan's father's wealth enables his son to attend Yale and to become acquainted with well-to-do people. The senior Monaghan charges his son to remind these "fine friends," these privileged individuals, that "every man is the slave of his own refuse" and that "your old dad," who made his money working with sewers, "is the king of them all" (415)
Sort Name: Unnamed Friends and Acquaintances of Monaghan
CharacterKey: Unnamed Friends and Acquaintances of Monaghan

Biography: The residents of Amiens who gather in the Cloche-Clos to celebrate the end of the War have had to endure great destruction and loss of life. They are "astonished" and "outraged" by the presence of a German aviator, even as a prisoner, in the bistro, and their resentment eventually boils over into violence (411).

The rioters at the Cloche-Clos in "Ad Astra" include these "three poilus" - i.e. French soldiers (423). "Poilu," originating in the word for "hairy," was a common name for French infantrymen in World War I, since many of them did not shave or get their hair cut.

CharacterName: Unnamed Wife of Captured German Aviator
Biography: The German prisoner's wife is described by her husband as "the daughter of a musician who wass peasant" (418). She lives in Bayreuth with their son, whom her husband has never seen. She keeps her husband informed by letter of significant changes in the family.
Sort Name: Unnamed Wife of Captured German Aviator
CharacterKey: Unnamed Wife of Captured German Aviator

Biography: The German prisoner reports that his own aristocratic family profoundly disapproves when he tells them "I haf married the daughter of a musician who was peasant" (418).

CharacterName: Unnamed Son of Captured German Aviator
Biography: Because of the War, this young son of the captured German aviator, who lives in Bayreuth with his mother, has never seen his father.
Sort Name: Unnamed Son of Captured German Aviator
CharacterKey: Unnamed Son of Captured German Aviator
Parent: Unnamed Captured German Aviator;Unnamed Wife of Captured German Aviator

Biography: It seems apparent that this Berlin woman is having an affair with one of the German prisoner's twin brothers; according to the captive, at least, in 1912 his brother is reported in the Berlin newspapers as "dead of a lady's husband" (418). This is the extent of her appearance in this story.
In "Ad Astra" the captured German aviator explains that one of his brothers was shot and killed by this resident of Berlin, presumably after the man discovered his wife's affair.
In the revolutionary fighting that breaks out in Berlin at the end of the war, this unnamed soldier assassinates the German aviator's brother Franz, a General serving on the army's general staff.

This icon represent the British officers who were placed in charge of the Indian soldiers serving in World War I. According to the subadar, when they ordered their troops to "'Go there and do this,' they would not stir" (415). A particularly dreadful consequence of their lack of responsible procedure is the death of almost an entire Indian battalion which advances on the enemy without loaded rifles.

"My people" is how the Indian subadar refers to these men, colonial troops brought to Europe to fight for England during the First World War (424). He also calls them "children" (425), who thought of the rifles they were issued as "spears" (424). His account suggests that their British officers were indifferent to their training. When a "whole battalion" went into battle without loading those rifles, less than twenty survived (425). (During World War I a British battalion at full strength contained a thousand men.)

World War I combat aviators were often measured by the number of enemy planes they shot down; each plane was assumed to be piloted by a single German officer. As reported by Hume, Sartoris shoots down three German aviators in his effort to avenge his brother's death (414). Monaghan asserts that he is responsible for the death of "thirteen Huns" - a derogatory term for German combatants during the War (416).

FirstAppearence: Western Front Inset: Skies over France
Biography: Apparently this aviator, whom the narrator refers to as the "Hun patrol leader," was the pilot who shot down Sartoris' brother's plane. He may in turn have been shot down by Sartoris; Hume says that Sartoris "must have got him" during the week he spends in the sky seeking to avenge his brother, but as the narrator says, "we didn't know" if the enemy pilot Sartoris shot down was the one he was after (414). (During the First World War, "Hun" was a derogatory term for the German enemy.)
This represents the "Tulls" among the five young men in Frenchman's Bend who are courting Eula Varner (130). He is presumably related to Vernon Tull and his wife, but the novel does not say how.

Binford is one of the five suitors in Frenchman's Bend who are courting Eula Varner. He is probably related to the Dewitt Binford who marries one of Flem's sisters. It's also possible but very unlikely that he is related to Lucius Binford, the man of the house in a Memphis brothel.
Hoke McCarron mentions his father very briefly in The Mansion (194). Hoke's father is described more fully in The Hamlet.
These prostitutes are the "white women" about whom Mink's mentor and guide has told him (317). Upon visiting the city, Mink purchases the company of these women.

The name "Das" is a common South Asian name, derived from Sanskrit. One of its meanings, however, is 'servant,' so it may be used by the subadar in the story not as a name but as a respectful title of address. In either case, this character is "the headman" who supervises the native military personnel; after the battalion's disastrous attack on German lines, he reluctantly admits to the subadar that his troops crossed No Man's Land with unloaded rifles, and almost their entire batallion was annihilated (425).

FirstAppearence: Western Front Inset: Skies over France
Biography: All we can say about "the other guy" who was flying with Sartoris' brother when he was shot down is that he was serving as a British aviator, presumably in the same "Camel squadron" as Sartoris; given all the non-English aviators in the story, we cannot even say where he was from (414). The Sopwith Camel was a standard single-seat British aircraft during World War I.

FirstAppearence: Western Front Inset: Skies over France
Biography: This "somebody" is the pilot who witnessed Sartoris "roosting about five thousand feet above an old Ack.W." - i.e. Sartoris is circling in his plane above a comrade flying a less maneuverable aircraft "for bait" to attract the German aviator who had shot down his brother (414). Ack.W. was military slang for a British World War I plane made by Armstrong Whitworth.

This woman is mentioned during Wilbur Provine's trial for making and selling illegal liquor. Judge Long tells her husband, "I'm going to send you to the penitentiary, not for making whiskey but for letting your wife carry water a mile and a half from that spring" (178).

Lonzo Hait (259) was in a scheme with I.O. Snopes to defraud the railroad by tethering a few of Snopes's mules to a blind curve on the railroad tracks; I.O. would then claim compensation from the company for his destroyed property. On one such occasion, Hait was killed along with the mules.
This sergeant accompanies the French officer when he confronts the aviators about bringing the German prisoner into the cafe.
Vernon Tull is a farmer in Frenchman's Bend; although he frequently appears in the Yoknapatawpha fictions, he plays a very minor role in this one.
OtherTexts: "Lizards in Jamshyd’s Courtyard", "Shingles for the Lord", "Spotted Horses", "The Hound", "Two Soldiers", As I Lay Dying, Sanctuary, The Hamlet, The Mansion

Biography: Mrs. Tull is mentioned in connection with her "sister's niece by marriage," who is I.O. Snopes's second wife. (As Cora Tull, this character plays a memorable part in As I Lay Dying.)
OtherTexts: "Shingles for the Lord", "Spotted Horses", As I Lay Dying, The Hamlet, The Mansion

Biography: Lincoln was the 16th President of the United States. He led the Union through the Civil War. By signing the Emancipation Proclamation in 1863, he freed the slaves in the Confederate states, including the Compson slaves in Mississippi.
OtherTexts: "Shall Not Perish", "Skirmish at Sartoris", "The Unvanquished", "Wash", Absalom, Absalom!, Go Down, Moses, The Unvanquished

CharacterName: Unnamed Mistress of Jason Compson IV
Biography: Jason Compson IV's mistress is described as "a big plain friendly brazenhaired pleasantfaced woman no longer very young, in round 'picture' hats and (in its season) an imitation fur coat" (339-40). The residents of Jefferson refer to her euphemistically as "his friend from Memphis" (340). During her visits, she is "domestic, uxorious, connubial," but on Sunday afternoons she is on the bus "back to Memphis" (340); she enables Jason to experience a measure of connubial bliss without endangering his newfound freedom in adulthood, after the death of his mother. (The "picture" in the term "picture hats" refers not to Hollywood movies but to 18th-century portraits of the British aristocracy; a "picture hat" is very wide-brimmed and elaborate.)
Sort Name: Unnamed Mistress of Jason Compson IV

Biography: The "passing female child" whom Benjy accosts is named Burgess in The Sound and the Fury (1929), which provides more details about Benjy's "fumbling abortive attempt" to engage with her (339). In this earlier account, Benjy's action is informed by his mourning for Caddy; the characterization of the event in the Appendix reflects Jason and the community's interpretation of Benjy's actions as lustful.

The soldier is described as merely "a shape (a man in khaki)," seen through Melissa Meek's tear-filled eyes (337). But he picks her up and installs her in a seat when she is overwhelmed by the crowds at the Memphis bus station. Although he is presumably part of the crowd of "soldiers and sailors enroute either to leave or to death" in the Second World War (337), Faulkner reasserts the humanity of those that make up the crowd through this soldier's stateside actions.

The bus station in Memphis is filled with "a few middleaged civilians but mostly soldiers and sailors enroute either to leave or to death and the homeless young women, their companions" (337). Faulkner's description allows the larger story of the Second World War to encroach on the narrative of the Compson family. Melissa Meek carries a picture of Caddy Compson standing next to a German officer in her handbag while she weaves through crowds of American soldiers preparing to fight Germany.
The "Appendix" refers briefly to the "brave and gallant men" who served under General Jason Compson II during the Civil War (330).

FirstAppearence: Western Front Inset: Skies over France
Biography: This Allied aviator helps Sartoris take revenge on the German pilot who shot down his brother by flying an out-moded airplane as the bait in Sartoris' trap. The narrator says "we" never knew who this aviator was (414).

This man, presumably Caddy's lover during World War II, is "a handsome lean man of middleage in the ribbons and tabs of a German staffgeneral," and is further characterized through the luxury of his surroundings: "a Cannebiere backdrop of mountains and palms and cypresses and the sea, an open powerful expensive chromiumtrimmed sports car," all of which are featured in "a slick magazine - a picture filled with luxury and money and sunlight" (344).

These "overalled men" are customers at the farmers' supply store where Jason IV owns a business buying and selling cotton (334). Although the customers are explicitly male, since the store is a "gloomy cavern which only men ever entered" (333), their race is not so clearly defined; the narrative indicates that the store serves "Mississippi farmers or at least Negro Mississippi farmers" (334), indicating that many, if not most of the customers are African-American.

Thorne Smith wrote wildly popular fantasy novels that were known for their provocative illustrations and plotlines that include much drinking, sex, and humor. His most popular novel, Topper, was made into a very successful movie starring Cary Grant in 1937. Perhaps most notably for the "wives of the bankers and doctors and lawyers" of Faulkner's Jefferson who borrow Smith's books from the library (333), Topper features a banker's wife who transforms from a social-climbing bore into a flashier and far more fun woman by the end of the novel.

The "highschool juniors and seniors" are described from the perspective of Melissa Meek, who emphasizes both their great height relative to her own petite stature and also their seemingly relentless desire to thwart her moderate attempts at book censure (333).

The "matrons" are described as a link between the Jefferson of the past and that of the present (333). Though some of them had also been part of the "old highschool class" with Melissa Meek and Caddy Compson, they are now "wives of the bankers and doctors and lawyers" of Jefferson (333). Their attention to respectability is evident in their attempts to keep their romance novels "carefully wrapped from view in sheets of Memphis and Jackson newspapers" (333).

Melissa Meek is the "county librarian, a mouse-sized and -colored woman who had never married," and also a former classmate of Caddy Compson who sees a photo of her in occupied France (333). Attempting to "save" Caddy enables Meek to transcend the characterization of her name, her profession, and her lifelong habits (335). She allows the library to become disorderly in her distraction, she bears "two feverish spots of determination in her ordinarily colorless cheeks" (333), she enters the feedstore where Jason IV works and where "only men ever entered," and she speaks to him, despite having refused to do so for many years. She also makes a determined trip to Memphis, despite being easily overwhelmed by crowds and "smaller than any other there" (337).

The unnamed "minor movingpicture magnate" Caddy Compson marries in Hollywood in 1920 and divorces in Mexico in 1925 is her second husband (332). His job suggests a shift in Caddy's lifestyle priorities, or in American cultural standards, from social status to celebrity, but the "minor" in his description suggests that her move has been a downward one.

These 121 Mississippi Representatives are the political colleagues of Clarence Snopes. With him included there are 122 total members of the House, which is historically accurate. Clarence addresses these men soon after assuming office.

Caddy Compson marries "an extremely eligible young Indianian" in 1910 (332). The text carefully notes she is "divorced by him" one year later, presumably when he discovers he is not the father of the child she carries (332). The unnamed figure in the Appendix corresponds with the character Sydney Herbert Head in The Sound and the Fury, a banker and former Harvard man who was expelled for cheating.

CharacterName: Unnamed Father of Caddy Compson's Child
Biography: The unnamed father of Caddy Compson's child is referred to in the "Appendix" only as "another man" (332). She is "two months pregnant" with his child when she marries her first husband. This 'other man' may be Dalton Ames, who is not mentioned in the "Appendix" but is Caddy's first sexual partner in The Sound and the Fury (1929). However, when in that novel Caddy's brother Quentin asks her in the context of her forthcoming marriage how many sexual partners she has had, she replies "I dont know too many" (115).
Sort Name: Unnamed Father of Caddy Compson's Child

Biography: These unnamed boarders - "juries and horse- and muletraders" - live in the Compson house after it has been vacated by the Compsons (331) .

The man with whom Caddy's daughter Quentin runs off is briefly described as a "pitchman in a travelling streetshow" (330). (When this nameless man appears in The Sound and the Fury, he is identified in both Benjy's and Jason's sections by his red tie.) The "Appendix" account of him adds that when he left with Quentin, he "was already under sentence for bigamy" (342).
The owner of the boardinghouse that used to be the Compson family home is a "countryman," which in this context refers to a rural person, as opposed to someone who lives in town (331).

Various "Sartorises" appear in many of Faulkner's fictions. In the "Appendix" they appear in a phrase - "the Compsons and Sartorises and their ilk" - describing how the "Snopeses" "took over the little town [of Jefferson] following the turn of the century" (338). The Sartorises represent the old plantation aristocracy that founded Yoknapatawpha, just as the Snopeses represent the class of parvenus who rise to positions of status in a newer South by largely unscrupulous means.
OtherTexts: "All the Dead Pilots", "Ambuscade", "My Grandmother Millard and General Bedford Forrest and the Battle of Harrykin Creek", "Retreat", "Skirmish at Sartoris", "The Unvanquished", "Vendee", Flags in the Dust, The Mansion, The Town, The Unvanquished

Biography: According to the Appendix, after the defeat of the South in the Civil War, Jefferson came to be "populated mainly" by "Snopeses" rather than "Compsons" (329). The enterprising, grasping, often unscrupulous members of the Snopes family appear in numerous Faulkner novels; in particular the Snopes Trilogy (1940, 1957, 1959) chronicles their rise from landless poor whites in Frenchman's Bend to positions of status in town.
OtherTexts: "Barn Burning", "By the People", "Centaur in Brass", "Lizards in Jamshyd’s Courtyard", "Mule in the Yard", "Shingles for the Lord", "Spotted Horses", "The Hound", "The Unvanquished", "There Was a Queen", "Vendee", As I Lay Dying, Flags in the Dust, Sanctuary, The Hamlet, The Mansion, The Reivers , The Sound and the Fury, The Town, The Unvanquished

Biography: The "Appendix" lists "the oldest names in the county" as "Holston and Sutpen, Grenier and Beauchamp and Coldfield" (330). Alexander Holston was one of the first three white men to settle Yoknapatawpha, but a tavern owner rather than a planter. Thomas Sutpen was born in a cabin in West Virginia but at the beginning of the Civil War was the owner of the country's largest, most prosperous plantation; his story is the narrative at the center of Absalom, Absalom! Louis Grenier brought the first slaves into Yoknapatawpha and is the man behind the name 'Frenchman's Bend'; he does not appear directly in any of the fictions. As Go Down, Moses describes, the Beauchamps who lived in Yoknapatawpha were all biracial: the illegitimate descendants of Old Carothers McCaslin; Faulkner is presumably not thinking of them here, but of the white plantation owners who lived in an adjoining county and who married into the McCaslin family. Goodhue Coldfield is also a character in Absalom, Absalom!; he was a storekeeper whose daughter Ellen married Sutpen.
OtherTexts: Requiem for a Nun, The Town

Biography: Most scholars assume the General Smith who appears here and also in "The Unvanquished" and "My Grandmother Millard" is Andrew Jackson Smith, who led the Union forces at the Battle of Tupelo in July, 1864. Faulkner had a particular reason to know this Smith: that same summer he led the Union soldiers who burned both Oxford (the original of Jefferson) and Ripley, where among the houses they destroyed was the home of Colonel William Falkner, the author's great-grandfather.
OtherTexts: "My Grandmother Millard and General Bedford Forrest and the Battle of Harrykin Creek", "The Unvanquished", The Unvanquished

Biography: The derisive term "carpetbagger" (derived from the material used to make cheap luggage) refers to Northerners who came into the South after the Civil War; depending on one's politics, they came either to reconstruct or to prey on the defeated South. Faulkner's carpetbaggers tend toward economic, rather than political, influence in Jefferson. Here, though Jason Compson II retains most of his land, the demands of this "New England carpetbagger" against the Compson estate prompt Jason to sell off small sections of the "solid square mile," thus enabling the Snopeses to "encroach" on his holdings (329).

There are two references in the "Appendix" to the slaves who lived in Yoknapatawpha before the Civil War. The term "slaves" appears only in reference to the "shiftless slaves" owned by the descendants of the Chickasaw tribe who remain in the region after the Indian Removal (329). But the Compson family, like the other "masters of plantations" in Yoknapatawpha, owned a number of slaves as well (328). Their existence is indicated by the "slavequarters" listed among the structures on the Compson estate (328), and by Jason IV's reference to Lincoln freeing them "from the Compsons" in 1865 (340).
This architect lays out both the Compson grounds and the Compson home, and shares the predilections of Faulkner's other architect characters for French furnishings.

The unnamed secessionists with whom Charles Stuart Compson is associated endeavored to "secede the whole Mississippi Valley from the United States and join it to Spain" (327). The plotters are headed by General James Wilkinson, whose real-life attempts to sell land to Spain were backed by a number of prominent Kentuckians.

The "acquaintance [of Charles Stuart Compson] named Wilkinson" in this text is the historical figure General James Wilkinson. Although Wilkinson served in the Continental Army during the Revolutionary War, and was the first Governor of the Louisiana Territory, he was also a spy for the Spanish government. Markedly unsuccessful as a military leader, he was immensely successful in defending himself against court-martials and other accusations of treason over a career in government that spanned several decades. The narrative describes him as "a man of considerable talent and influence and intellect and power" (327).

Tarleton was known in England as an outstanding military leader during the Revolutionary War, which he joined at the age of 21. In America, however, Tarleton had a reputation for savagery on the field; he and his men participated in the capture of Charleston, and later became infamous for what Americans called the "Waxhaws Massacre" in South Carolina in 1780.

The "Boon or Boone" mentioned twice in the "Appendix" is most famous for exploring and settling what was then part of Virginia, and what is now Kentucky, creating a route through the Cumberland Gap in the Appalachian Mountains that many settlers would later follow. The settlement referred to in the text is probably Boonesborough, one of the first settlements west of the Appalachians. In the first mention Boone is portrayed as a peer of Quentin MacLachan Compson, simply "a neighbor" who had "already established a settlement" on the frontier (326), the second mention conjures up a larger-than-life figure who keeps company with Robinson Crusoe (330).

The "English king" against whom Quentin MacLachan Compson fought (326) was George II, notable here for having put an end to the Jacobite rebellions regarding succession to the British crown. Compson's homeland in Scotland, Culloden Moor, was the site of the last major Jacobite uprising. There, George II's son defeated the Jacobites, many of whom were executed, or (like the first American Compson) fled the country.

AKA: Charles Stuart;The Young Pretender;Charles Edward Stuart
Biography: The "dispossessed" king for whom the grandfather of the first Compson in Yoknapatawpha fought (325) is Charles Edward Stuart, who spent most of his life in exile but claimed to be the rightful king of Britain as part of the Jacobite line of Catholic monarchs. His hope of claiming the throne ended in 1746, when the Jacobites were defeated in a final battle in Scotland. Charles himself is perhaps best remembered for a romantic escape through the Scottish countryside after that loss. Although he was seen by many during his flight from Scotland, no one turned him in to claim the hefty reward offered by the British government. He spent the remainder of his life on the European continent.

After achieving fame as a military leader in wars with Britain and the American Indians, Andrew Jackson was President of the United States between 1829 and 1837. His 1830 Indian Removal Act relegated Native Americans to land west of the Mississippi River; their 'removal' claimed thousands of lives. Here, Jackson's portrait is framed by this policy; he is the "Great White Father with a sword" (326). His rough frontier persona is emphasized, rather than the high office he achieved: "An old duellist, a brawling lean fierce mangy durable imperishable old lion" (326). Quick to take offense, Jackson spent a significant portion of his time in the White House defending the terms of his marriage to Rachel Donelson Robards. He married Rachel after she separated from her first husband, but not before her divorce was finalized, thus invalidating the Jacksons' marriage. They remarried, but the stigma of bigamy remained.
OtherTexts: "A Name for the City", Requiem for a Nun

Biography: Having separated from her first husband, Rachel Donelson met and married Andrew Jackson, who would go on to be the President of the United States. Her divorce from her first husband, however, was not finalized before she married Jackson, and thus Donelson and Jackson were forced to marry a second time. The murky circumstances surrounding their marriage became fodder for political attacks against Jackson. Rachel Jackson's sudden death due to heart attack, shortly before her husband assumed office, prompted him to resent his political enemies for, as he saw it, driving her to an early grave. Faulkner's characterization of Jackson's obsession with his wife's honor is supported by the epitaph on Rachel Jackson's grave: "A being so gentle and so virtuous slander might wound, but could not dishonor."

The Indian agent in "Appendix" also runs a successful "tradingpost store" (325). Indian agents represented the U.S. government in its interactions with indigenous people. Since a primary job of the agent is to ensure that land sales concerning Native Americans are recorded and licensed, Jason Compson I's receipt of a square mile of land from Ikkemotubbe is likely made all the easier by his becoming first clerk for and then partner with the Chickasaw Agent in Jefferson (328).

"Napoleon's marshals," otherwise known as the Marshals of the Empire, are characterized here as a "glittering galaxy of knightly blackguards" (325). Napoleon reinstated the rank of marshal, the highest military rank in France, in 1804, and appointed 26 marshals, 18 of them in one month. These men were notable for reflecting his own preferences, rather than for having reached a given level of accomplishment. Nearly all lived luxurious lifestyles, at least in part due to their newly elevated status.

Napoleon's driving ambition, as Emperor of France, was to expand France's domain in Europe. The allusion to him here, at the beginning of the "Appendix," serves as a template for several of the characters Faulkner will create: dictatorial leaders driven to expand their holdings at all costs.

This displaced aristocrat, "a Chevalier of France" who was "born too late" to be one of Napoleon's marshals, calls his "fosterbrother" Ikkemotubbe "Du Homme" - from which comes the chief's new name, "Doom" (325). The "Appendix" does not explain his relationship with Ikkemotubbe; that story that is more fully described "Red Leaves" and Go Down, Moses. "Chevaliers" held a minor aristocratic rank in pre-Revolutionary France, and bring to the "Appendix" a precedent of aristocracy laced with decadence.
OtherTexts: "A Courtship", "A Justice", "Red Leaves", "The Old People", Go Down, Moses

Biography: Ikkemotubbe, or "Doom," as he rechristens himself, is described as a "dispossessed American king" (325). He is the chief of the Chickasaw tribe that once occupied a "vast lost domain" in Northern Mississippi (325). In the "Appendix," he is described as "a man of wit and imagination as well as a shrewd judge of character, including his own" (325). Although in other Faulkner texts, Doom is often described as powerful, intimidating, and ruthless, his actions in the "Appendix" indicate that his power has limits. He trades a square mile of land so that he and his people can "proceed in peace" to Oklahoma, merely attempting to mitigate the discomfort of his tribe's uprooting when the U. S. shifted from 'voluntary migration' to 'forced migration' to 'remove' the Indian population from southern frontier.
OtherTexts: "A Courtship", "A Justice", "A Name for the City", "Delta Autumn", "Red Leaves", "The Bear", "The Old People", Absalom, Absalom!, Go Down, Moses, Intruder in the Dust, Requiem for a Nun, The Reivers , The Town

Biography: Luster, Benjy Compson's caretaker, is described as "A man, aged 14. Who was not only capable of the complete care and security of an idiot twice his age and three times his size, but could keep him entertained" (343). Luster is the son of Frony Gibson, and the grandson of Dilsey Gibson.
OtherTexts: Absalom, Absalom!, The Sound and the Fury

Biography: TP is the second son of Roskus and Dilsey Gibson, and brother of Versh and Frony. In The Sound and the Fury, we see "T. P." take on caretaking duties for Benjy Compson, like the other members of this black family. In the "Appendix," however, "TP" (the periods are removed from his name) is given a freer existence: wearing "fine bright cheap intransigent clothes" "on Memphis's Beale Street" (343).
OtherTexts: "That Evening Sun", The Sound and the Fury

Biography: Frony is the daughter of Dilsey, sister to TP, and mother of Luster. Although in The Sound and the Fury she was associated, both as a child and as an adult, with the Compson estate, in the "Appendix" she has moved on. She "married a pullman porter and went to St. Louis to live and later moved back to Memphis to make a home for her mother" (343).
OtherTexts: "That Evening Sun", The Sound and the Fury

Biography: Dilsey, her daughter Frony, her son TP, and her grandson Luster have separate entries in the "Appendix Compson" and in our database. This entry, however, represents the collective group referred to in the "Appendix" as "Dilsey's family," who lived as a group in the "one servant's cabin" left on the Compson property (330). If Faulkner is thinking of the "family" as he depicts it in The Sound and the Fury and "That Evening Sun," it also includes Dilsey's husband, Roskus, and another son, Versh.
Quentin MacLachan Compson's father was a printer in Glasgow; apparently he died when his son was still a child (326).
Quentin MacLachan Compson's mother died when he was a child. Her family was based in "the Perth highlands" in Scotland (326).

CharacterName: Unnamed Family of Quentin MacLachan Compson's Mother
Biography: Quentin MacLachan Compson's mother's family lives in the Scottish highlands at Perth, where he is raised by them.
Sort Name: Unnamed Family of Quentin MacLachan Compson's Mother
CharacterKey: Unnamed Family of Quentin MacLachan Compson's Mother

Biography: Quentin MacLachan Compson, or Quentin I, is the "son of a Glasgow printer, orphaned and raised by his mother's people" (326) in the Perth Highlands. He is driven from Culloden Moor, presumably as a result of the rebel Jacobites' last battle against the Hanovarian government of Britain, which occurred at that site in 1746, and flees across the Atlantic to Carolina. In 1779, at age eighty, he flees from the American Revolutionary War to Kentucky with his grandson. His entry in the "Appendix" is marked by repeated references to his tartan, which accompanies him through every stage of his migration.
Parent: Father of Quentin MacLachan Compson;Mother of Quentin MacLachan Compson

Biography: Named after Charles Stuart the Young Pretender, for whom his father fought in Scotland, Charles Stuart Compson served under the British commander Banastre Tarleton in the American Revolutionary War; Charles Stuart was thus part of the military serving the monarchy his father had formerly opposed. After he is "left for dead" on a colonial battlefield (326), and with an amputated leg, he joins his son and father in Harrodsburg, Kentucky, where he tries a series of ventures: teaching school, gambling, and plotting against the American government to give Spain the Mississippi Valley. Charles Stuart is notably "vocal and vociferant," a trait that contributes to his self-imposed exile from the United States (327).

Jason Lycurgus Compson, or Jason Compson I, the first Compson in Yoknapatawpha, was given his "flamboyant" name by his father (328). In 1799, as an "infant," he was taken by his grandfather from Carolina to Kentucky (326). He arrived at the Indian agency in what would become Jefferson in 1811. By racing his mare against the horses of Ikkemotubbe's men, Jason I won the "solid square mile of land" that would become the Compson Domain (328). The Compson Domain is Jason I's most significant contribution to the Compson family history, so it is not surprising that his entry in the "Appendix" is dominated by a description of the property and its development, rather than the life of the man who established it.

Named for his grandfather, Quentin MacLachan Compson II is characterized as a "brilliant and gallant governor" (335), and is frequently trotted out as proof of the Compson line's success. Because of him, the Compson home is referred to as "the Governor's house" (329), a description that holds long after his death.
OtherTexts: "A Justice", "A Name for the City", "Skirmish at Sartoris", The Mansion, The Sound and the Fury, The Unvanquished

Biography: General Compson is said to have had "three avatars": "the one as son of a brilliant and gallant statesman, the second as a battleleader of brave and gallant men, the third as a sort of privileged pseudo-Daniel Boone-Robinson Crusoe, who had not returned to juvenility because actually he had never left it" (330). General Compson begins the tradition of Compson men who "fail at everything [they touch] save longevity or suicide" (330). He suffers two majors losses in the Civil War, at Shiloh and Resaca. He "put the first mortgage on the still intact square mile" and continues to mortgage and sell pieces of the Compson domain until "he died quietly on an army cot in the hunting and fishing camp in the Tallahatchie River bottom where he passed most of the end of his days" (329). His death occurs in 1900.
OtherTexts: "A Justice", "My Grandmother Millard and General Bedford Forrest and the Battle of Harrykin Creek", "Skirmish at Sartoris", "The Bear", Absalom, Absalom!, Go Down, Moses, Intruder in the Dust, Requiem for a Nun, The Reivers , The Sound and the Fury, The Town, The Unvanquished

Biography: Jason Compson III inherits a weighty family tradition, as the descendant of an explorer, a governor, and a general. He himself, however, is concisely characterized as a "cultured dipsomaniac who sold the last of his patrimony not to buy drink but to give one of his descendants at least the best chance in life he could think of" (335). He was "bred for a lawyer," but showed little signs of application to the profession (330).
OtherTexts: "Lion", "That Evening Sun", Go Down, Moses, The Mansion, The Sound and the Fury, The Town
